text: If the investor ceases to have significant influence over an associate, how should the investment be treated?

choices.text: The investment should be treated at cost
It should still be treated using equity method
It should be treated in accordance with PFRS 9
The investment should be frozen at the date at which the investor ceases to have significant influence

explanation: When significant influence ceases, the investment is accounted for under PFRS 9 at fair value through profit or loss or other comprehensive income.

text: How is the impairment test carried out for an investment in associate?

choices.text: The goodwill is separated from the rest of the investment and is impairment tested individually
The entire carrying amount of the investment is tested for impairment by comparing the recoverable amount with the carrying amount
The carrying amount of the investment should be compared with the market value
The recoverable amounts of all investments in associates should be assessed together to determine whether there has been an impairment on all investments

explanation: Under PAS 28, the entire carrying amount of the investment, including any goodwill, is tested for impairment as a single asset.

text: Under PAS 40, investment property is defined as

choices.text: Property held to earn rentals or for capital appreciation
Property held for sale in the ordinary course of business
Identifiable nonmonetary asset without physical substance
Property held for use in the production and supply of goods or services and property held for administrative purposes

explanation: Investment property is property held to earn rentals or for capital appreciation or both.

text: Which of the following items is an example of investment property?

choices.text: Property that is leased to another entity under a finance lease
Property held for short -term sale in the ordinary course of business
Property that is being constructed or developed on behalf of third parties
Property that is being constructed or developed for future use as investment property

explanation: Property under construction or development for future use as investment property qualifies as investment property under PAS 40.

text: Which of the following could not be reported as investment property?

choices.text: Real estate held for an undetermined future use
Property held by the entity and lease out under one or more operating leases
Property owned by the entity and leased out under one or more operating leases
Property owned by the entity and leased out to another entity under a finance lease

explanation: When leased under a finance lease, the property is derecognized and cannot be classified as investment property by the lessor.

text: Which of the fo llowing statements best describe owner -occupied property under PAS 40 Investment Property? I. Property held to earn rentals II. Property held for administrative purposes III. Property held for sale in the ordinary course of business IV. Property held for use in the prod uction and supply of goods and services

choices.text: I and II
I and IV
II and IV
III and IV

explanation: Owner-occupied property is used in the production or supply of goods or services or for administrative purposes.

text: An investment property should be measured initially at

choices.text: Cost
Cost less accumulated impairment losses
Depreciable cost less accumulated impairment losses
Fair value less accumulated impairment losses

explanation: Investment property is initially measured at cost, including transaction costs.

text: An entity purchased land for future use and appropriately classifies the land as investment property. What valuation model may be used to report the land?

choices.text: Fair value model or revaluation model
Fair valu e through other comprehensive income or revaluation model
Cost model or fair value model
Cost model or revaluation model

explanation: Under PAS 40, the entity may use the cost model or the fair value model.

text: A gain rising from a change in the fair value of an investment property for which an entity has opted to use the fair value model is r ecognized in

choices.text: Net profit or loss for the year
General reserve in the shareholders equity
Valuation reserve in the stockholders equity
None of the above

explanation: Under the fair value model, changes in fair value are recognized directly in profit or loss.

text: A property interest that is held by a lessee under an operating lease may be classified and accounted for as an investment property provided the following criteria are met choose the exception

choices.text: The property meets the definition of investment property
The operating lease is accounted for as if it were a finance lease
The lessee uses the FV model in measuring the property interest
The lessee uses either the cost or FV model in measuring the property interest

explanation: PAS 40 requires the fair value model only when an operating lease is accounted for as investment property by the lessee.

text: An entity has investment property that leases to another entity. The entity uses the fair value model to report investment property. Which o f the following statements is true?

choices.text: The entity should value the equipment at cost less accumulated depreciation and less accumulated impairment losses
The entity should report the increase in fair value in other comprehensive income for the period
The entity depreciates the equipment using normal depreciation method
The entity does not record depreciation on the investment property

explanation: When using the fair value model, no depreciation is charged on investment property.

text: Transfers from investment property to property, plant and equipment are appropriate

choices.text: When there is change of use
Based on t he entitys discretion
Only when the entity adopts the fair value model
The entity can never transfer investment property into another classification

explanation: Transfer is only made when there is evidence of change in use.

text: When an owner -occupied property is transferred to an investment property at fair value, a decrease in the carrying amount of the property to its fair value at the date of transfer

choices.text: Is carried directly to equity
Is absorbed by retained earnings
Is recognized in profit and loss at all times
Is recognized in profit and loss, or, for a revalued prop erty, charged against the revaluation surplus to the extent of its credit balance

explanation: If the property is revalued, the decrease is first charged against revaluation surplus.

text: Which of the following additional disclosures must be made when an entity chooses the cost model as its accounting policy for investment property?

choices.text: Fair value of the property
Net realizable value of the property
Present value of the property
Value in use of the property

explanation: The fair value must still be disclosed even if the cost model is used.

text: Which is not an essential characteristic of property, plant and equipment?

choices.text: The property, plant and equipment are subject to depreciation
The property, plant and equipment are tangible assets
The property, plant and equipment are used in production or supply of goods and services, for rental and administrative purposes
The property, plant and equipment are expected to be used over a period of more than one year

explanation: While property, plant, and equipment are tangible, this is not an essential characteristic for classification.

text: The depreciable amount of an item of property, plant and equipment is the

choices.text: Cost of the asset less its residual value
Net amount which the enterprise expects to obtain for an asset at the end of its useful life after deducting the expected costs of disposal
Amount of cash or cash equivalent paid or the fair value of other consideration given to acquire an asset at the time of its acquisition or construction
Amount at which an asset is recognized in the balance sheet after deducting any accumulated depreciation and accumulated impairment losses thereon

explanation: The depreciable amount is the cost of the asset minus its residual value.

text: Carrying amount is

choices.text: Cost of an asset or the amount substituted for cost in the financial statements, less its residual value
Amount of cash or cash equivalent paid or the fair value of the other consideration given to acquire an asset at the time of its acquisition or construction
Net amount which the enterprise expects to obtain for an asset at the end of its useful life after deducting the expected costs of disposal
Amount at which an asset is recognized in the balance sheet after deducting any accumulated depreciation and accumulated impairment loss

explanation: Carrying amount is the value at which the asset is recognized after depreciation and impairment.

text: The cost of property, plant and equipment comprises all of the following except

choices.text: Its purchase price, including import duties and non-refundable purchase taxes, after deducting trade discounts and rebates
Cost of opening a new facility or introducing a new product or service
Any cost directly attributable to bringing the asset to the condition or location necessary for it to be capable of operating in the manner intended by management
The initial estimate of the costs of dismantling and removing the item and restoring the site on which it is located and for which the entity has a present obligation

explanation: Opening new facilities or introducing new products is not part of the cost of acquiring property, plant, and equipment.

text: Directly attributable costs include all of the following except

choices.text: Cost of site preparation, initial delivery, handling and installation
Professional fees such as for architects and engineers
Estimated cost of dismantling and removing the asset and restoring the site, to the extent that it is recognized as a provision
Initial operating losses incurred prior to an asset achieving planned performance

explanation: Operating losses incurred before the asset is in use should not be capitalized.

text: As to land, capitalizable incidental costs do not include?

choices.text: Legal fees for establishing clean title
Commission paid to broker
Cost of permanent improvement such as grading, leveling and other landscaping
Expenditures for fence, water system, sidewalk and paving

explanation: Permanent improvements like grading are usually capitalized but do not fall under incidental costs.

text: Land improvements

choices.text: Are subject to depreciation
Should be included in the cost of land
Should be deducted from the cost of land
Should be charged as an expense in the year purchased

explanation: Land improvements, unlike land itself, are depreciable assets.

text: A lessee incurred costs to construct office space in a leased warehouse. The estimated useful life of the office is ten years. The remaining term of the renewable lease is fifteen years. The cost should be

choices.text: Expensed as incurred
Capitalized as leasehold improvements and depreciated over ten years
Capitalized as leasehold improvements and depreciated over fifteen years
Capitalized as leasehold improvements and expensed in the year in which the lease expires

explanation: Leasehold improvements should be depreciated over the shorter of the lease term or useful life of the improvements.

text: Plant assets purchased on a long-term credit contract should be accounted for at

choices.text: The total value of the future payments
The future amount of the future payments
The present value of the future payments
None of these

explanation: Plant assets on credit should be recorded at the present value of future payments.

text: When accounting for property, plant and equipment, an entity

choices.text: Must use the cost model for land
Must use the cost model for presenting the assets
May elect to use the cost model or the revaluation model on any asset class
May elect to use the cost model or the revaluation model on any individual asset

explanation: Entities can choose between cost or revaluation models for asset classes but not individual assets.

text: Which of the following most accurately reflects the concept of depreciation?

choices.text: The process of charging the decline in value of an economic resource to income in the period in which the benefit occurred
A method of allocating asset cost to an expense account in a manner which closely matches the physical deterioration of the asset
The process of allocating the cost of tangible asset to expense in a systematic and rational manner to those periods expected to benefit from the use of the asset
An accounting concept that allocates the portion of an asset used up during the year to the contra asset account for the purpose of properly recording the fair value of the asset

explanation: Depreciation allocates the cost of an asset over its useful life systematically.

text: Which is incorrect concerning depreciation of PPE?

choices.text: The depreciation method used should reflect the pattern in which the assets economic benefits are consumed by the enterprise

The depreciation method should be reviewed at least annually and, if the pattern of consumption of benefits has changed, the depreciation method should be changed currently and prospectively as a change in estimate
Depreciation should be charged to the income statement, unless it is included in the carrying amount of another asset
Depreciation begins when the asset is available for use and continues until the asset is derecognized and becomes idle

explanation: Depreciation stops once the asse

text: Which of the following statements regarding depreciation is true, according to PAS 16, Property, Plant and Equipment?

choices.text: The total cost of an asset must eventually be depreciated
The annual depreciation charge should be constant over the life of the asset
An asset must be depreciated from the date of its purchase to the date of sale
If the carrying amount of an asset is less than the residual value, depreciation is not charged

explanation: The total cost of the asset, less its residual value, is eventually depreciated over the asset's useful life.

text: A variety of depreciation methods can be used to allocate the depreciable amount of an asset over its useful life. Which statement is incorrect?

choices.text: Straight-line depreciation results in a constant charge over the useful life if the asset's residual value does not change
The diminishing balance method results in a decreasing charge over the useful life
The units of production method results in a charge based on the expected use or output
The sum of years digits method results in an increasing charge over the useful life

explanation: The sum of years digits method results in a decreasing depreciation charge over the useful life.

text: The sum-of-the-years-digits method of depreciation

choices.text: Results in residual value being ignored
Means the carrying amount should not be reduced below residual value
Means the denominator is the years remaining at the beginning of the year
All of these describe the sum-of-years-digits method

explanation: The carrying amount should never be reduced below the asset's residual value under the sum-of-years-digits method.

text: Depreciation is a variable expense if the depreciation method used is

choices.text: Declining balance
Sum of the years digits
Straight line
Units of production

explanation: Depreciation is variable when using the units of production method, as it is based on actual usage or output.

text: Depreciation is computed on the original cost without deducting estimated salvage value under which of the following depreciation methods?

choices.text: Declining balance
Productive Output
Straight line
Units of production

explanation: The declining balance method computes depreciation on the original cost, ignoring the salvage value.

text: Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: A gain on disposal of a noncurrent asset is classified as revenue
Assets are depreciated even if the fair value exceeds carrying amount
Land and building are not accounted for separately when acquired together
A noncurrent asset acquired as the result of an exchange of assets is not recognized

explanation: Even if the fair value exceeds the carrying amount, depreciation must still be charged based on the asset's cost or carrying value.

text: If an entity is able to determine reliably the fair value of either the asset received or the asset given up, which is used in measuring the cost of the asset received?

choices.text: Fair value of asset given up
Fair value of asset received
Carrying amount of asset given up
Either fair value of asset given up or fair value of asset received

explanation: The cost of the acquired asset is determined based on the fair value of either the asset given up or the asset received.

text: The cost of a non-monetary asset acquired in exchange for another non-monetary asset with commercial substance is usually recorded at

choices.text: Either the fair value of the asset given, or the asset received
The fair value of the asset given, and a gain or loss is recognized
The fair value of the asset given and a gain but not a loss may be recognized
The fair value of the asset received if it is equally reliable as the fair value of the asset given

explanation: When a non-monetary asset is exchanged, it is recorded at the fair value of the asset received or the asset given, whichever is more reliable.

text: Accounting recognition should be given to the gain realized on a non-monetary exchange of plant asset, except when the exchange has

choices.text: Commercial substance and additional cash is paid
No commercial substance and additional cash is paid
Commercial substance and additional cash is received
All of these cause recognition of a gain

explanation: A gain is not recognized when there is no commercial substance in the exchange, even if additional cash is paid.

text: Which of the following nonmonetary exchange transactions has commercial substance?

choices.text: Exchange of assets with no difference in future cash flows
Exchange of products by entities in the same line of business with no difference in future cash flows
Exchange of assets with a difference in future cash flows
Exchange of an equivalent interest in similar productive assets that causes the entities involved to remain in essentially the same economic position

explanation: A nonmonetary exchange has commercial substance if the future cash flows change as a result of the exchange.

text: When payment for an item of property, plant equipment is deferred beyond normal credit terms, the difference between the cash price and total payment is

choices.text: Charged to Retained Earnings
Capitalized as Property, Plant Equipment
Interest expense over the credit period
Interest expense over the useful life of the asset

explanation: The difference between the cash price and total payment represents interest, which is expensed over the credit period.

text: When a closely held corporation issues equity shares in exchange for land, the land should be recorded at the

choices.text: Total par value of shares issued
Current market value of the land
Total book value of the shares issued
Current market value of the shares issued

explanation: The land should be recorded at the fair market value of the shares issued, as this reflects the exchange value.

text: When an item of property, plant and equipment is acquired by issuing debt securities, which is the best basis for establishing the historical cost of the acquired asset?

choices.text: Face value of the bonds issued
Historical cost of the asset received
Fair value of the asset received
Fair value of the bond issued

explanation: The historical cost is best established using the fair value of the asset received in exchange for the debt securities.

text: Assets received in donation should

choices.text: Should not be depreciated
Be expensed upon receipt
Be depreciated based on their fair value at the time of the donation
Be depreciated based on their book value at the time of the donation

explanation: Donated assets are typically depreciated based on their fair value at the time of donation.

text: An expenditure made in connection with a machine being used should be

choices.text: Expensed immediately if it merely extends the useful life but does not improve the quality
Expensed immediately if it merely improves the quality but does not extend the useful life
Capitalized if it maintains the machine in normal operating condition
Capitalized if it increases the quantity of units produced by the machine

explanation: Expenditures that improve the machine's ability to produce more units should be capitalized as they enhance the asset's value.

text: Which of the following expenditures subsequent to property acquisition cannot be added to the asset carrying amount?

choices.text: Costs of modification of an item of property that will extend its useful life
Costs of upgrading parts to achieve substantial improvements in quality of output
Costs of material repairs that did not increase the asset life nor productive capacity
Costs of adopting new production processes that enabled substantial reduction in operating costs

explanation: Repairs that do not extend the asset’s useful life or enhance its productive capacity are expensed, not capitalized.

text: A change in the estimated useful life of a building

choices.text: Is not allowed by generally accepted accounting principles
Affects the depreciation on the building beginning with the year of the change
Must be handled as a retroactive adjustment to all accounts affected, back to the year of the acquisition of the building
Creates a new account to be recognized on the income statement reflecting the difference in net income up to the beginning of the year of the change

explanation: A change in the estimated useful life of a building affects depreciation starting from the year of the change, not retroactively.

text: Rock Company acquired equipment on January 1, 2017. Rock used the straight-line depreciation with a useful life of 15 years and no residual value for this equipment. On January 1, 2021, Rock estimated that the remaining life of the equipment was six years with no residual value. How should this change be accounted for?

choices.text: Revising future depreciation annually to equal the original cost divided by six
Revising future depreciation annually to equal the carrying amount of January 1, 2021 divided by six
Disclosing the effect of the change on each year's earnings, but maintaining the depreciation as originally determined
Revising future depreciation annually to equal the depreciable amount divided by six

explanation: The change in the estimated useful life requires the remaining depreciable amount to be allocated over the revised remaining life from the point of change.

text: When the revaluation model is used for reporting property, plant and equipment, the gain or loss should be included in

choices.text: Income for the period
Gain from revaluation in the income statement
An extraordinary gain or loss in the income statement
A revaluation surplus account in other comprehensive income -----

explanation: Under the revaluation model, increases in an asset's carrying amount are recognized in other comprehensive income and accumulated in equity under the heading of revaluation surplus.

text: Under the revaluation model for accounting for property, plant and equipment

choices.text: Asset must be revalued quarterly
Asset must be revalued annually
Asset must be revalued bi-annually
There is no rule regarding the frequency of revaluation -----

explanation: PAS 16 does not specify a mandatory frequency for revaluation. The frequency depends on the changes in fair values of the items being revalued.

text: When an entity chooses the revaluation model as the accounting policy for measuring property, plant and equipment, which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Revaluation of property, plant and equipment must be made at least every three years
When an asset is revalued, the entire class of property, plant and equipment to which that asset belongs must be revalued
Increase in an assets carrying amount as a result of the first revaluation must be recognized as a component of profit or loss
When an asset is revalued, individual asset within a class of property, plant and equipment to which that asset belongs can be revalued -----

explanation: Under PAS 16, when an item of property, plant and equipment is revalued, the entire class of property, plant and equipment to which that asset belongs must be revalued to maintain consistency in financial reporting.

text: When a balance is carried in an asset revaluation surplus account in relation to an asset that has been derecognized, it is acceptable under PAS 16 to

choices.text: Transfer the balance to retained earnings
Transfer the balance to share capital account
Transfer the balance to a provision account for future asset revaluations
Recognize the balance in profit or loss of the period in which the asset was derecognized -----

explanation: When an asset is derecognized, the revaluation surplus included in equity in respect of that asset may be transferred directly to retained earnings.

text: Which statement is incorrect concerning the class of property, plant and equipment to be revalued?

choices.text: When an item of property, plant and equipment is revalued, the entire class property, plant and equipment to which that asset belongs shall be revalued
A class of property, plant and equipment is a grouping of assets of a similar nature and use in an entitys operation
The items within a class of property, plant and equipment are revalued selectively
A class of assets may be revalued on a rolling basis provided revaluation of the class of assets is completed within a short period of time and provided the revaluations are kept up to date -----

explanation: This is incorrect because when an item is revalued, the entire class must be revalued, not just selective items within the class.

text: An asset is impaired when

choices.text: Its recoverable amount exceeds its carrying amount
Its carrying amount exceeds its recoverable amount
Its fair value less costs to sell is less than its value in use
Its net selling price is less than its value in use -----

explanation: An asset is impaired when its carrying amount exceeds its recoverable amount, which is the higher of fair value less costs to sell and value in use.

text: Recoverable amount is

choices.text: The amount at which an asset is recognized in the balance sheet after deducting accumulated depreciation and accumulated impairment losses
The higher of an assets fair value less costs to sell and its value in use
The amount obtainable from the sale of an asset in a bargained transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties
The discounted present value of estimated future cash flows -----

explanation: Recoverable amount is defined as the higher of an asset's fair value less costs to sell and its value in use.

text: Which statement is incorrect in determining recoverable amount?

choices.text: If the carrying amount is less than fair value less costs to sell or value in use, it is not necessary to calculate the other amount
If fair value less costs to sell cannot be determined, then recoverable amount is value in use
For assets to be disposed of, recoverable amount is fair value less costs to sell
None of the above -----

explanation: All the statements are correct regarding the determination of recoverable amount.

text: Fair value less cost to sell is I. The amount obtainable from the sale of an asset in an arms length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties less cost of disposal II. The present value of future cash flows expected to be derived from an asset

choices.text: I only
II only
Both I and II
Neither I nor II -----

explanation: Fair value less costs to sell is the amount obtainable from the sale of an asset in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties less costs of disposal. Statement II describes value in use, not fair value less costs to sell.

text: Value in use of an asset is equal to the

choices.text: Undiscounted future net cash flows from the use of the asset
Undiscounted future net cash flows from the use and eventual disposition of the asset
Discounted future net cash flows from the use of the asset
Discounted future net cash flows from the use and eventual disposition of the asset -----

explanation: Value in use is the present value of the future cash flows expected to be derived from an asset, including both its use and eventual disposition.

text: Under PAS 36, the impairment rules for long-lived assets apply to all of the following except

choices.text: Land
Financial instruments
Building currently used in the business
Minicomputers used to run a production process -----

explanation: PAS 36 does not apply to financial instruments, which are covered by different accounting standards.

text: An entity has determined that the fair value of a cash generating unit exceeds carrying amount. Which of the following statements is correct concerning this test of impairment?

choices.text: Goodwill should be written down as impaired
Goodwill should be retested at the entity level
Impairment is not indicated, and no additional analysis is necessary
The assets and liabilities should be valued to determine if there has been an impairment of goodwill -----

explanation: If the fair value of a cash generating unit exceeds its carrying amount, no impairment exists and no further testing is required.

text: Under the reporting requirements for impaired assets, impairment losses for assets to be held and used shall be reported

choices.text: As an extraordinary item
As a component of discontinued operations
As a component of income from continuing operations
As a change in accounting estimate -----

explanation: Impairment losses for assets to be held and used are recognized in profit or loss as a component of income from continuing operations.

text: A cash generating unit is

choices.text: The smallest business segment
Any group of assets that generates cash flows
Any group of assets that is reported separately to management
The smallest group of assets that generates independent cash flows from continuing use -----

explanation: A cash generating unit is the smallest identifiable group of assets that generates cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets.

text: Where cash generating unit is disposed of, any goodwill associated shall

choices.text: Be written off against retained profits
Be included in the calculation of gain or loss
Not be included in the calculation of gain or loss
Not be written off to the income statement entirely -----

explanation: When a cash generating unit is disposed of, any goodwill associated with that unit should be included in the calculation of the gain or loss on disposal.

text: PFRS 6 applies to expenditures incurred

choices.text: When a specific area is being developed and preparations for commercial extraction are being made
In extracting mineral resources and processing the resource to make it marketable or transportable
When searching for an area that may want detailed exploration, even though the entity has not yet obtained the legal rights to explore a specific area
When the legal rights to explore a specific area have been obtained, but the technical feasibility and commercial viability of extracting a mineral resource are not yet demonstrated -----

explanation: PFRS 6 specifically applies to the exploration and evaluation phase of mineral resources, which occurs after obtaining legal rights but before demonstrating technical feasibility and commercial viability.

text: Which of the following expenditures would never qualify as an exploration and evaluation asset?

choices.text: Expenditure for exploratory drilling
Expenditure for acquisition of rights to explore
Expenditures related to the development of mineral resources
Expenditures for activities in relation to evaluating the technical feasibility and commercial viability of extracting mineral resources -----

explanation: Development expenditures occur after the exploration and evaluation phase and are therefore not considered exploration and evaluation assets under PFRS 6.

text: Does PFRS 6 require an entity to recognize exploration and evaluation expenditures as assets?

choices.text: No, such expenditure is always expensed in profit or loss incurred
Yes, but only to the extent such expenditure is recoverable in future periods
Yes, but only to the extent required by the entitys accounting policy for recognizing exploration and evaluation of assets
Yes, but only to the extent the technical feasibility and commercial viability of extracting the associated mineral resources have been demonstrated -----

explanation: PFRS 6 allows entities to develop their own accounting policies for recognizing exploration and evaluation assets, subject to certain requirements.

text: An entity is required to consider which of the following in developing accounting policy for exploration and evaluation activities?

choices.text: Recent pronouncements of standard-setting bodies
Whether the accounting policy results in information that is relevant and reliable
The requirements and guidance in PFRS dealing with similar and related issues
The definitions, recognition criteria, and measurement concepts or assets, liabilities, income and expenses in the Conceptual Framework -----

explanation: When developing accounting policies for exploration and evaluation activities, entities must consider the fundamental concepts in the Conceptual Framework.

text: Which measurement model applies to exploration and evaluation assets subsequent to initial recognition?

choices.text: The cost model
The revaluation model
The recoverable amount model
Either the cost model or the revaluation model -----

explanation: PFRS 6 allows entities to choose between the cost model and the revaluation model for measuring exploration and evaluation assets after initial recognition.

text: Which of the following is not a disclosure requirement by PFRS 6?

choices.text: Information about commercial reserve quantities
Accounting policies for exploration and evaluation expenditures including the recognition of exploration and evaluation assets
Information that identifies and explains the amounts recognized in the financial statements arising from the exploration of mineral resources
The amounts of assets, liabilities, income and expenses and operating and investing cash flows arising from the exploration and evaluation of mineral resources -----

explanation: While information about commercial reserve quantities may be important, it is not specifically required by PFRS 6. The standard focuses on financial statement disclosures related to exploration and evaluation activities.

text: Of the following costs related to the development of mineral resources, which one should not be included in depletable cost?

choices.text: Acquisition cost of the mineral resource deposit
Exploration cost
Tangible equipment cost associated with machinery used to extract the mineral resource
Intangible development cost such as drilling cost, tunnel, and shaft -----

explanation: Tangible equipment costs are depreciated separately and are not included in the depletable cost of mineral resources.

text: Depletion expense

choices.text: Is usually part of cost of goods sold
Includes tangible equipment cost in the depletion base
Excludes intangible equipment cost from the depletion base
Excludes restoration cost from the depletion base -----

explanation: Depletion expense represents the cost of natural resources consumed and is typically included in cost of goods sold as the resources are extracted and sold.

text: The most common method of recording depletion for accounting purposes is the

choices.text: Percentage of depletion method
Straight line
Production or output method
Decreasing charge method -----

explanation: The production or output method is the most common method for recording depletion as it directly relates the depletion expense to the actual extraction of the natural resource.

text: These are assistance by government in the form of transfers of resources to an entity in return for past or future compliance with certain conditions relating to the operating activities of the entity

choices.text: Government assistance
Government grants
Government subvention
Government premium -----

explanation: Government grants are defined as assistance by government in the form of transfers of resources to an entity in return for past or future compliance with certain conditions relating to the operating activities of the entity.

text: It is an action by government designed to provide an economic benefit specific to an entity or range of entities qualifying under certain criteria

choices.text: Government assistance
Government grant
Government subvention
Government premium -----

explanation: Government assistance is defined as an action by government designed to provide an economic benefit specific to an entity or range of entities qualifying under certain criteria.

text: Which can be considered a government assistance?

choices.text: Imposition of trading constraints on competitors
Improved facilities, such as irrigation or water supply
Free technical or marketing advice and provision of guarantee
Infrastructure by improvement to the general transport and communication network -----

explanation: Government assistance includes free technical or marketing advice and provision of guarantees, as these provide specific economic benefits to qualifying entities.

text: Under PAS 20, a government grant shall be recognized when

choices.text: The entity has complied with all the conditions attaching to the grant
The entity has complied with all the conditions attaching to the grant and grant will be received
There is reasonable assurance that the entity will comply with the conditions attaching to the government grant
There is reasonable assurance that the entity will comply with the conditions attaching to the grant and the grant will be received -----

explanation: PAS 20 requires that government grants should be recognized when there is reasonable assurance that the entity will comply with the conditions attaching to the grant and the grant will be received.

text: Which of the following statements is true about government grant?

choices.text: Grant related to an asset is accounted for either as deferred income or deduction from the carrying amount of the asset
Grant related to income is presented as the other income, separate line item or a deduction from the related expense
A forgivable loan from government is treated as government grant if there is reasonable assurance that the entity will meet the terms for the forgiveness of the loan
All of these statements are true above government grant -----

explanation: All the statements are correct regarding government grants under PAS 20, including the treatment of asset-related grants, income-related grants, and forgivable loans.

text: Which of the following is true regarding the income approach for government grant?

choices.text: Depreciation is higher if the grant is an adjustment of the asset
Depreciation is higher and net income lower if the grant is an adjustment to the asset
Depreciation is higher if the grant is a deferred revenue and net income is not affected
Depreciation is higher and net income is lower if the grant is recorded as deferred revenue -----

explanation: When a grant is treated as an adjustment to the asset, the depreciation expense is higher (as it's based on the net amount after deducting the grant), resulting in lower net income.

text: In case of non-monetary grant, which of the following is prescribed by PAS 20?

choices.text: Record the grant at a value estimated by management
Record the asset at replacement cost and the grant at a nominal value
Record both the grant and the asset at fair value of the non-monetary asset
Record only the asset at fair value and not recognize the fair value of the grant -----

explanation: PAS 20 requires that both the grant and the asset should be recorded at fair value in the case of non-monetary grants.

text: Which is incorrect concerning recognition of government grants as income?

choices.text: Grants in recognition of specific expenses should be recognized as income over the period of the related expense
Grants related to depreciable assets should be recognized as income over the periods and in proportion to the depreciation of the related assets
Grants related to non-depreciable assets requiring fulfillment of certain conditions should be recognized as income over the periods which bear the cost of meeting the conditions

Government grants that become receivable as compensation for expenses or losses already incurred or for the purpose of giving immediate financial support to the enterprise with no future related costs should be recognized as an adjustment of retained earnings -----

explanation: This is incorrect because such grants should be recognized in profit or loss, not as an adjustment to retained earnings.

text: Which of these disclosures is not required by PAS 20?

choices.text: The accounting policy adopted for government grants, including methods of presentation adopted in the financial statements
Unfulfilled conditions and other contingencies attaching to government assistance
The names of the government agencies that gave the grants along with the dates of sanction of the grants by these government agencies and the dates when cash was received in case of monetary grants
The nature and extent of government grants recognized in the financial statements and an indication of other forms of government assistance from which the entity has directly benefited -----

explanation: PAS 20 does not require disclosure of the names of government agencies or specific dates of sanction and receipt of grants.

text: When government grants related to income become repayable due to non-fulfillment of a condition attaching to it, the repayment choose the incorrect statement

choices.text: Should be treated as a change in accounting estimate
Should be accounted for prospectively
Should be first applied against any unamortized deferred income
Should be recognized as a debit to retained earnings to the extent that the repayment exceeds any such deferred income -----

explanation: This is incorrect because the repayment of a government grant should be treated as a change in accounting policy, not as a change in accounting estimate.

text: Under PAS 23, borrowing costs can be capitalized as part of the asset when

choices.text: The asset is a qualifying asset
The asset is a qualifying asset and it is not probable that the borrowing costs will result in future economic benefits to the entity
The asset is a qualifying asset and it is probable t hat the borrowing costs will result in future economic benefits to the entity and the costs can be measured reliably
The asset is a qualifying asset and it is probable that the borrowing costs will result in future economic benefits to the entity, but the costs cannot be measured reliably

explanation: PAS 23 requires three conditions for capitalization: the asset must be a qualifying asset, it must be probable that the borrowing costs will result in future economic benefits, and the costs must be measurable reliably.

text: Which of the following may not be considered a qualifying asset?

choices.text: A toll bridge that usually takes more than a year to build
A ship that normally takes one or two years to accomplish
An expensive private jet can be purch ased from a local vendor
A power generation plant that normally takes two years to construct

explanation: A qualifying asset is one that necessarily takes a substantial period of time to get ready for its intended use or sale. A private jet that can be purchased from a local vendor would not typically require a substantial period of time to get ready for use.

text: When computing capitalizable interest cost, what is the concept of avoidable interest?

choices.text: A cost of capital charge for equity
The total interest cost actually incu rred
That portion of average accumulated expenditures on which no interest cost was incurred
That portion of total interest cost which would not have been incurred if expenditures for asset construction had not been made

explanation: Avoidable interest is the amount of interest cost that could have been avoided if the asset construction expenditures had not been made.

text: Interest cost that is capitalized should

choices.text: Be written off over the remaining term of the debt
Not be written off until the related asset is fully depreciated or disposed of
Be accumulated in a deferred charge account and written off equally over a 40 -year period
None of these

explanation: Capitalized interest becomes part of the cost of the asset and is written off through depreciation over the asset's useful life, not through any of the methods described in the options.

text: Which of the following statements is true regarding capitalization of interest?

choices.text: Interest cost capitalized in connection with the purchase of land to be used as a building site should be debited to the land account and not the building account
The amount of i nterest cost capitalized during the period should not exceed the actual interest cost incurred
When excess borrowed funds not immediately needed for construction are temporarily invested, any interest earned should be recorded as interest revenue

The minim um amount of interest to be capitalized is determined by multiplying a weighted -average interest rate by the amount of average accumulated expenditures on qualifying asset during the period

explanation: The amount of interest cost capitalized during a period should never exceed the actual interest cost incurred during that period.

text: Which of the following statements about the capitalization of bor rowing costs as part of the costs of qualifying asset is true?

choices.text: Capitalization always continues until the asset is brought into use
Capitalization always commences as soon as expenditure of the asset is incurred
Capitalization always commences as soon as in terest on relevant borrowings is being incurred
If funds come from general borrowings, the amount to be capitalized is based on the weighted average cost of borrowing

explanation: When funds are borrowed generally, the amount of borrowing costs eligible for capitalization is determined by applying a capitalization rate to the expenditures on that asset, where the capitalization rate is the weighted average of the borrowing costs applicable to the borrowings of the entity.

text: The period of time during which capitalization of interest begins and when capitalization of interest ends is

choices.text: From the time funds are borrowed until the asset is substantially complete and ready for its intended use
From the time the first expenditures are incurred until the asset is substantially complete and ready for its inten ded use
From the time the first expenditures are incurred until no further interest cost is being incurred
From the time the first expenditures are incurred until activities necessary to get the asset for its intended use have begun

explanation: Capitalization of borrowing costs should commence when expenditures for the asset are being incurred, borrowing costs are being incurred, and activities necessary to prepare the asset for its intended use are in progress. It should cease when substantially all the activities necessary to prepare the asset for its intended use are complete.

text: An entity commences a new construction project which is to be financed by borrowing. The key dates for the current year are as follows March 15 Loan interest relating to the project starts to be incurred June 15 Technical site planning commences June 30 Expenditure s on the project start to be incurred July 15 Construction work commences From what date can the entity commence the capitalization of borrowing costs?

choices.text: March 15
June 15
June 30
July 15

explanation: Capitalization can begin when all three conditions are met: expenditures are being incurred, borrowing costs are being incurred, and activities necessary to prepare the asset are in progress. In this case, all three conditions are met on June 30.

text: Capitalization of borrowing costs shall be suspended

choices.text: Only during temporary periods of delay
At no instance at all as capitalization has already commenced
Only upon agreement by management and the construction company
Only during extended periods of delay in which active development is delayed

explanation: Capitalization should be suspended during extended periods in which active development is interrupted, but not during temporary delays.

text: A co mpany constructed machinery for its own use. A bank loan specifically financed this property both during and after the construction. How much of the interests incurred should be reported as interest expense?

choices.text: All interests incurred
Interests incurred after completion
Interests incurred before completion
Zero

explanation: Interest costs should be capitalized during the construction period, but once the asset is ready for its intended use, any subsequent interest costs should be expensed.

text: Which of the following is not a disclosure requirement under PAS 23?

choices.text: Accounting policy adopted for borrowing costs
Amount of borrowing costs capitalized during the period
Capitalization rate used to determine the amount of borrowing costs eligible for capitalization
Segregation of assets that are qualifying assets on the balance sheet as a disclosure in the financial statement notes

explanation: PAS 23 does not require the segregation of qualifying assets on the balance sheet. The other options are required disclosures under the standard.

text: Which of the following statements is true about biological assets?

choices.text: Biological assets must be valued at cost
Biological assets are only found in Biotech entities
Biological assets do not generally have future economic benefits
Biological assets are living animals or plants and must be reported as a separate item in the statement of financial position -----

explanation: Biological assets are living animals or plants, and PAS 41 requires them to be presented as a separate line item in the statement of financial position.

text: According to PAS 41, Agriculture, which of the following criteria must be satisfied before a biological asset can be recognized in an entity's financial statements? I. The entity controls the asset as a result of past events II. It is probable that economic benefits relating to the asset will flow to the entity III. An active market for the asset exists IV. The asset comes from a homogeneous biological group

choices.text: I and II only
II and III only
I, II and III only
I, II and IV only -----

explanation: The recognition criteria for biological assets are the same as for other assets: control as a result of past events and probable future economic benefits. The existence of an active market or homogeneous biological group is not a recognition criterion.

text: The cost of agricultural produce harvested from biological assets is

choices.text: Cost
Fair value
Lower of cost or net realizable value
Fair value less estimated point of sale costs at the point of harvest -----

explanation: PAS 41 requires agricultural produce harvested from biological assets to be measured at fair value less estimated point-of-sale costs at the point of harvest.

text: Which of the following is not dealt with by PAS 41?

choices.text: The accounting for biological assets
The processing of agricultural produce after harvesting
The initial measurement of agricultural produce harvested from biological assets
The accounting treatment of government grant received in respect of biological assets -----

explanation: PAS 41 does not deal with the processing of agricultural produce after harvest, which is covered by other standards such as PAS 2 (Inventories).

text: Agricultural activity

choices.text: Is the harvested product of the entity's biological asset
Is the detachment of agricultural produce from a biological asset or the cessation of a biological asset's life processes
Is the management by an entity of the biological transformation of biological assets for sale, into agricultural produce, or into another biological asset
Relates to the processes of growth, degeneration, production and procreation that can cause changes of quantitative or qualitative nature in a biological asset -----

explanation: Agricultural activity is defined as the management by an entity of the biological transformation of biological assets for sale, into agricultural produce, or into additional biological assets.

text: Agricultural activity results in which of the following types of assets?

choices.text: Biological assets only
Agricultural produce only
Both biological assets and agricultural produce
Financial assets, contingent assets and agricultural produce -----

explanation: Agricultural activity can result in both biological assets (living animals or plants) and agricultural produce (harvested product of the entity's biological assets).

text: Where there is a long aging or maturation process after harvest, the accounting for such products is dealt with by

choices.text: PAS 41, Agriculture
PAS 2, Inventory
PAS 16, Property, Plant and Equipment
PAS 40, Investment Property -----

explanation: Products that undergo a long aging or maturation process after harvest are accounted for under PAS 2 (Inventories) rather than PAS 41.

text: According to PAS 41, Agriculture, which of the following items would be classified as biological asset?

choices.text: Chickens
Eggs
Land in mango orchard
Oranges -----

explanation: Chickens are living animals and therefore classified as biological assets. Eggs, oranges, and land are not biological assets.

text: Which of the following items would be classified as agricultural produce, according to PAS 41, Agriculture?

choices.text: Apple
Butter
Bush
Tree -----

explanation: An apple is the harvested product of a biological asset (apple tree) and is therefore classified as agricultural produce.

text: Under PAS 41, which of the following would be classified as a product that is the result of processing after harvest?

choices.text: Bananas
Cheese
Cotton
Wool -----

explanation: Cheese is a product that results from processing after harvest (processing of milk) and is therefore not covered by PAS 41.

text: Biological assets are measured at

choices.text: Cost
Fair value less costs to sell
Lower of cost or net realizable value
Net realizable value -----

explanation: PAS 41 requires biological assets to be measured at fair value less costs to sell, except when fair value cannot be measured reliably.

text: Under PAS 41, any gain arising from the initial recognition of biological assets e.g., when a calf is born shall

choices.text: Be recognized in the profit or loss
Be recognized in the other comprehensive income
Not be recognized although note disclosure is required
Be deferred and amortized over the life of the biological asset -----

explanation: Gains and losses arising from the initial recognition of biological assets and from changes in fair value less costs to sell are recognized in profit or loss.

text: Which of the following is unlikely to be used in fair value measurement of biological asset?

choices.text: Quoted market price
External independent valuation
The most recent market transactions price
The present value of the expected net cash flows from the asset -----

explanation: While present value calculations might be used in some cases, they are less likely to be used for biological assets as market prices or recent transaction prices are generally available and preferred.

text: Land that is related to agricultural activity is valued

choices.text: At fair value
At fair value in combination with the biological asset that is being grown on the land
At the resale value separate from the biological asset that has been grown on the land
In accordance with PAS 16, Property, Plant and Equipment, or PAS 40, Investment Property -----

explanation: Land related to agricultural activity is accounted for under PAS 16 or PAS 40, not under PAS 41.

text: Where there is a production cycle of more than one year, PAS 41 encourages separate disclosure of the

choices.text: Physical change only
Price change only
Physical change and price change
Total change in value -----

explanation: PAS 41 encourages separate disclosure of physical changes and price changes in biological assets with production cycles of more than one year.

text: A required disclosure for biological assets. I. Aggregate gain or loss arising during the current period on initial recognition of biological assets and agricultural produce and from the change in fair value less costs to sell of biological assets. II. Description of each group of biological assets

choices.text: I only
II only
Both I and II
Neither I nor II -----

explanation: Both the aggregate gain or loss and the description of each group of biological assets are required disclosures under PAS 41.

text: Which is not a characteristic of an intangible asset?

choices.text: The asset lacks physical substance
The asset is used in production or supply of goods and services, for rental to others or for administrative purposes
The asset provides future economic benefits
The asset has an indeterminate useful life -----

explanation: An intangible asset can have either a finite or indefinite useful life. Having an indeterminate useful life is not a characteristic of an intangible asset.

text: Under PAS 38, which of the following is a criterion that must be met in order for an item to be recognized as an intangible asset other than goodwill?

choices.text: The fair value can be measured reliably
The item is identifiable and lacks physical substance
The item is expected to be used in the production or supply of goods or services
The item is part of the activities aimed at gaining new scientific or technical knowledge -----

explanation: The key criteria for recognizing an intangible asset are identifiability and lack of physical substance. The other options are not required criteria.

text: An asset meets the identifiability criterion in the definition of an intangible when I. It is separable, meaning, the asset is capable of being separated from the entity and sold, transferred, licensed, rented or exchanged regardless of whether the entity intends to do so II. It arises from contractual or other legal rights, regardless of whether those rights are transferable or separable from the entity or from other rights and obligations

choices.text: I only
II only
Both I and II
Neither I nor II -----

explanation: An intangible asset meets the identifiability criterion when it is either separable (can be separated and sold) or arises from contractual or legal rights.

text: Under PAS 38, an intangible asset that was acquired separately shall initially be recognized at

choices.text: Recoverable amount
Either cost or fair value at the choice of the acquirer
Fair value
Cost -----

explanation: An intangible asset acquired separately should be initially recognized at cost, which includes its purchase price and any directly attributable costs of preparing the asset for its intended use.

text: After initial recognition, an intangible asset shall be carried using the I. Cost model, meaning, at cost less any accumulated amortization and any accumulated impairment losses II. Revaluation model, meaning at revaluated amount, being the fair value on the date of revaluation, less any subsequent accumulated amortization and any subsequent accumulated impairment losses

choices.text: I only
II only
Either I or II
Neither I nor II -----

explanation: After initial recognition, an entity can choose either the cost model or the revaluation model for measuring intangible assets, though the revaluation model is only allowed if there is an active market for the asset.

text: An entity that acquires an intangible asset may use the revaluation model for subsequent measurement only if

choices.text: The intangible asset is a monetary asset
An active market exists for the intangible asset
The cost of the intangible asset can be measured reliably
The useful life of the intangible asset can be reliably determined -----

explanation: The revaluation model can only be used if there is an active market for the intangible asset, which is rare for most intangible assets.

text: Which of the following costs should be capitalized when incurred?

choices.text: Costs to internally generated goodwill
Filing fees for a patent
Organizational costs
Research and development costs -----

explanation: Filing fees for a patent are directly attributable costs that should be capitalized. The other options are typically expensed as incurred.

text: Which of the following statements concerning patents is correct?

choices.text: Legal cost incurred to successfully defend a patent should be capitalized and amortized over the patent's remaining useful life
Legal fees and other direct costs in registering a patent should be capitalized and amortized over 5 years
Research and development contract services purchased from others and used to develop a patent should be capitalized and amortized over the patent's useful life
Research and development costs incurred to develop a patent should be capitalized and amortized over 17 years -----

explanation: Legal costs incurred to successfully defend a patent are considered to extend the patent's useful life and should be capitalized and amortized over the remaining useful life.

text: Which of the following confers exclusive right to conduct business in a particular territory?

choices.text: Franchise
Leasehold improvement
Patent-copyright
Trademark -----

explanation: A franchise confers the exclusive right to conduct business in a particular territory under the franchisor's name and system.

text: Which of these is expensed as incurred by the franchisee for a franchise with an estimated useful life of ten years?

choices.text: Initial amount paid to the franchisor for the franchise
Any initial direct costs incurred in obtaining the franchise
Legal fees paid to the franchisee's lawyers to obtain the franchise
Periodic payments to the franchisor based on the franchisee's revenues -----

explanation: Periodic payments to the franchisor based on revenues are operating expenses and should be expensed as incurred. The other costs should be capitalized and amortized.

text: A large publicly held company has developed and registered a trademark during 2021. How should the cost of developing and registering the trademark be accounted for?

choices.text: Charged to an asset account that should not be amortized
Expensed as incurred
Amortized over 20 years if in accordance with management's evaluation
Amortized over its useful life or 17 years whichever is shorter -----

explanation: Costs of developing and registering a trademark should be expensed as incurred, as they are considered research and development costs.

text: Goodwill should be recorded in the accounting records only when

choices.text: It is internally generated
It is acquired through the acquisition of another business
A firm reports above normal earnings for five or more consecutive years
It can be established that a definite benefit or advantage has resulted to a firm from some items such as good name, capable staff or reputation -----

explanation: Goodwill should only be recorded when it is acquired through a business combination. Internally generated goodwill cannot be recognized.

text: Goodwill represents the excess of the cost of an acquired company over the

choices.text: Sum of the fair values assigned to plant assets less liabilities assumed
Sum of the fair values assigned to identifiable assets acquired less liabilities assumed
Sum of the fair values assigned to tangible assets acquired less liabilities assumed
Sum of the fair values assigned to intangible assets acquired less liabilities assumed -----

explanation: Goodwill is calculated as the excess of the cost of acquisition over the fair value of identifiable assets acquired less liabilities assumed.

text: What is required with respect to accounting for goodwill?

choices.text: Goodwill should be recorded and never adjusted
Goodwill should be amortized over a five-year period
Goodwill should be amortized over the expected useful life
Goodwill should be recorded and periodically evaluated for impairment -----

explanation: Goodwill should not be amortized but should be tested for impairment at least annually or more frequently if events or circumstances indicate that it might be impaired.

text: Which of the following is not a method of computing goodwill?

choices.text: Capitalize excess earnings
Discount the excess earnings for a limited number of years
Capitalize total average earnings and subtract the fair value of net assets
All of these are methods of computing goodwill -----

explanation: All the methods listed (capitalizing excess earnings, discounting excess earnings, and capitalizing total earnings) are valid methods of computing goodwill.

text: Costs incurred by a company that may develop its own goodwill internally should be

choices.text: Expensed in the period incurred
Capitalized and amortized over the useful life of the goodwill
Capitalized and amortized as the company profits increased
Capitalized and amortized over a period not exceeding 40 years -----

explanation: Internally generated goodwill cannot be recognized as an asset. All costs related to developing goodwill internally should be expensed as incurred.

text: The process of assigning the cost of an intangible by charges against periodic revenue, in some systematic and rational manner, is called

choices.text: Depletion
Amortization
Depreciation
Allocation -----

explanation: Amortization is the systematic allocation of the cost of an intangible asset over its useful life.

text: Amortization of specific intangible assets results primarily from application of the

choices.text: Cost principle
Full-disclosure principle
Matching principle
Revenue principle -----

explanation: Amortization of intangible assets is based on the matching principle, which requires that costs be matched with the revenues they help generate.

text: In accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, which of the following methods of amortization is normally recommended for intangible assets?

choices.text: Sum of years digits method
Straight line
Units of production
Double declining balance -----

explanation: The straight-line method is normally recommended for amortizing intangible assets unless there is a more appropriate method based on the pattern of consumption of the asset's economic benefits.

text: Which of the following represents the maximum amortization period mandated by GAAP for amortizable intangible assets?

choices.text: 10 years
20 years
40 years
No arbitrary cap on the useful life has been established -----

explanation: There is no arbitrary cap on the useful life of amortizable intangible assets. The useful life should be based on the expected period over which the asset will generate economic benefits.

text: A purchased patent has a remaining legal life of 8 years. It should be

choices.text: Expensed in the year of acquisition
Amortized over a period of 10 or 20 years
Amortized over its useful life, if less than 8 years
Amortized over 8 years regardless of the useful life -----

explanation: A patent should be amortized over its useful life, which may be shorter than its legal life. If the useful life is less than 8 years, it should be amortized over the shorter period.

text: Legally speaking, a patent should be amortized over

choices.text: Twenty years
The useful life
The useful life or twenty years, whichever is longer
The useful life or twenty years, whichever is shorter -----

explanation: A patent should be amortized over the shorter of its useful life or its legal life (20 years).

text: An intangible asset with an indefinite life is one where

choices.text: The length of life is over 20 years
The directors feel that the intangible asset will not lose value in the foreseeable future
There is no foreseeable limit on the period over which the asset will generate cash flows
There is a contractual or legal arrangement that lasts for a period in excess of five years -----

explanation: An intangible asset has an indefinite useful life when there is no foreseeable limit on the period over which the asset is expected to generate net cash inflows.

text: An intangible asset with an indefinite life is accounted for as follows

choices.text: Amortized and no impairment test
Amortized and impairment tests annually
No amortization but tested for impairment annually
Amortized and tested for impairment if there is a trigger event -----

explanation: Intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are not amortized but must be tested for impairment annually.

text: In relation to the amortization of intangible assets, if an intangible asset has a finite useful life

choices.text: It must be amortized over that life
It is not subject to an annual amortization charge
It must be amortized over a period not exceeding 40 years
It must be amortized across a period not exceeding 5 years -----

explanation: An intangible asset with a finite useful life must be amortized over that life.

text: The residual value of an intangible asset should be presumed zero, unless I. There is a commitment by a third party to purchase the asset at the end of its useful life II. There is an active market for the asset and residual value can be determined by reference to that market and it is probable that such market will exist at the end of the asset's useful life

choices.text: Both I and II
Neither I nor II
II only
I only -----

explanation: The residual value of an intangible asset should be presumed to be zero unless both conditions are met: there is a commitment by a third party to purchase the asset, or there is an active market for the asset.

text: On January 1, 2016, an intangible asset with a 15-year estimated useful life was acquired. On January 1, 2021, a review was made of the estimated useful life and it was determined that the intangible asset had an estimated total useful life of 25 years since it was acquired. As a result of the review

choices.text: On January 1, 2021, a review was made of the estimated useful life and it was determined that the intangible asset had an estimated total useful life of 25 years since it was acquired. As a result of the review
The original cost at January 1, 2016 should be amortized over a 20-year life
The original cost at January 1, 2016 should be amortized over the remaining 10-year life
The unamortized cost at January 1, 2021 should be amortized over a 20-year life

explanation: When the useful life is revised, the remaining carrying amount should be amortized over the revised remaining useful life. In this case, the remaining carrying amount should be amortized over the remaining 20 years (25 years total - 5 years already passed).

text: A computer software purchased as an operating system for the hardware or as integral part of a computer-controlled machine tool that cannot operate without the specific software shall be treated as

choices.text: Expense
Inventory
Intangible assets
Property, plant and equipment -----

explanation: Software that is an integral part of the related hardware should be treated as property, plant and equipment.

text: Research and development costs, under prevailing practice, may be accounted for as follows

choices.text: R and D costs related to successful projects should be capitalized others expensed
R and D costs related to unsuccessful projects should be capitalized others expensed
R and D costs should be expensed as incurred
R and D costs should be allocated between successful and unsuccessful projects -----

explanation: Under PAS 38, research and development costs should be expensed as incurred, except for development costs that meet specific criteria for capitalization.

text: The proper accounting treatment for the costs incurred in creating software product is

choices.text: To capitalize all costs until the software is sold
To capitalize all costs as incurred until a detailed program design or working model is created
To charge research and develop expense only if the computer software has alternative future use
To charge research and development expense when incurred until technological feasibility has been established for the product -----

explanation: Costs incurred before technological feasibility is established should be expensed as research and development costs.

text: According to IAS 38 Intangibles, in order to be able to capitalize development outlays an entity must be able to demonstrate the following I. Technical feasibility and intention of completing the asset so it will be available for use or sale II. Its ability to reliably measure the expenditure on the development of the asset III. Ability to use or sell the asset IV. How the asset will generate probable future economic benefits

choices.text: I, II and IV only
II, and IV only
I, II, III and IV
II, III and IV only -----

explanation: All four criteria must be met to capitalize development costs: technical feasibility, reliable measurement, ability to use/sell, and probable future economic benefits.

text: Which of the following costs related to computer software is capitalized to an intangible asset account?

choices.text: Cost of customer service
Cost to duplicate discs and manuals for sale
Development costs preceding technological feasibility
Coding and testing costs incurred after technological feasibility but before completing product master -----

explanation: Costs incurred after technological feasibility is established but before the product is ready for sale should be capitalized.

text: A research and development activity for which the cost would be expensed as incurred is

choices.text: Modification of the design of a product or conceptual formulation and design of a possible product alternative
Trouble shooting in connection with breakdowns during commercial production
Routine design of tools
Engineering, follow-through in an early phase of commercial production -----

explanation: These activities are considered research and should be expensed as incurred.

text: A research and development activity for which the cost would be expensed as incurred is

choices.text: Design, construction and testing of preproduction prototypes and models
Quality control during commercial production
Periodic design changes to existing products
Adaptation of an existing capability to a particular requirement or customer need -----

explanation: These activities are considered research and should be expensed as incurred.

text: Which is not considered a research and development activity?

choices.text: Routine on-going efforts to refine, enrich or improve quality of existing product
Laboratory research aimed at discovery of new knowledge
Conceptual formulation and design of possible product or process
Design, construction and operation of a pilot plant -----

explanation: Routine efforts to improve existing products are not considered research and development activities.

text: Which of the following is the proper treatment of the cost of equipment used in research and development activities that will have alternative future use?

choices.text: Expensed in the year in which the research and development project started
Capitalized and depreciated over the term of the research and development project
Capitalized and depreciated over the estimated useful life
Either capitalized or expensed but not both, depending on the term of the research and development project -----

explanation: Equipment with alternative future use should be capitalized and depreciated over its estimated useful life.

text: Which statement is incorrect concerning research and development?

choices.text: Research is original and planned investigation undertaken with the purpose of gaining new scientific and technical knowledge and understanding

Development is application of research finding or other knowledge to a plan or design for production of new or substantially improved material, device, product, process, system or service, prior to the commencement of commercial production or use
Expenditure on research shall be recognized as an expense when it is incurred

If an entity cannot distinguish the research phase from the development phase of an internal project to create an intangible asset, the entity shall treat the expenditure on that project as if it were incurred in the development phase only -----

explanation: If an entity cannot distinguish between research and development phases, the expenditure should be treated as if it were incurred in the research phase only.

text: Operating losses incurred during the start-up years of a new business should be

choices.text: Accounted for and reported like the operating losses of any other business
Written off directly against retained earnings
Capitalized as a deferred charge and amortized over five years
Capitalized as an intangible asset and amortized over a period not to exceed 20 years -----

explanation: Start-up losses should be accounted for and reported like any other operating losses.

text: Start-up costs including legal fees incurred to organize a new entity should be

choices.text: Expensed as incurred
Capitalized and amortized over 5 years
Capitalized and never amortized
Capitalized and amortized over 40 years -----

explanation: Start-up costs, including legal fees, should be expensed as incurred.

text: Current liabilities include

choices.text: Only obligations which are expected to be settled within the normal operating cycle
Only obligations which are due to be settled within one year from balance sheet date
Obligations which are expected to be settled within the normal operating cycle and obligations which are due to be settled within one year from balance sheet date
Refinanced long-term debt falling due within one year from balance sheet

explanation: Current liabilities include both obligations expected to be settled within the normal operating cycle and those due within one year from the balance sheet date.

text: A present obligation should be accrued when

choices.text: It is probable at the date of the financial statements that a liability has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated
The obligation has been incurred on the date of the financial statements and the amount may be material
It is probable that the obligation will be incurred in a future period and the amount can be reasonably estimated
It is probable at the date of the financial statements that an obligation has been incurred and the amount may be material

explanation: A present obligation should be accrued when it is probable that a liability exists and the amount can be reasonably estimated.
