text: An outflow of resources embodying future economic benefits it is regar ded as probable when

choices.text: The event is more likely than not to occur, meaning, the probability that the event will occur is greater than the probability that the event will not occur
The probability that the event will not occur is greater than the probabilit y that the event will occur
The probability that the event will occur is the same as the probability that the event will not occur
The probability that the event will occur is 90 likely

explanation: An outflow is considered probable when the likelihood of occurrence is greater than 50% (more likely than not).

text: It is an event that creates a legal or constructive obligation becau se the enterprise has no other realistic alternative but to settle the obligation

choices.text: Event after balance sheet date
Adjusting event
Non -adjusting event
Obligating event

explanation: An obligating event is one that creates a legal or constructive obligation because the enterprise has no realistic alternative but to settle the obligation.

text: Which is not an essential characteristic of an accounting liability?

choices.text: The liability is the present obligation of a particular enterprise
The liability arises from past transaction or event
The settlement of the liability requires an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits
The liability is payable to a specifically identified payee

explanation: A liability does not need to be payable to a specifically identified payee. The other options are essential characteristics of a liability.

text: Which of the following items would be excluded from current liabilities?

choices.text: Normal accounts payable which had been assigned by the creditor to a finance company
Long-term debt callable within one year or less because the debtor violated a debt provision
A short-term debt which at the discretion of the entity can be rolled over at least twelve months after the balance sheet date
A long-term liability callable or due on demand by the creditor even though the creditor has given no indication that the debt will be called

explanation: A short-term debt that can be rolled over for at least twelve months after the balance sheet date should be classified as non-current.

text: Which item is not a current liability?

choices.text: Unearned revenue
Stock dividends distributable
The currently maturing portion of long-term debt
Trade accounts payable

explanation: Stock dividends distributable is not a liability but rather a component of shareholders' equity.

text: An accrued expense can be best described as an amount

choices.text: Paid and currently matched with earnings
Paid and not currently matched with earnings
Not paid and not currently matched with earnings
Not paid and currently matched with earnings

explanation: An accrued expense is an expense that has been incurred but not yet paid, and is matched with current earnings.

text: Which of the following is an accrued liability?

choices.text: Cash dividends payable
Wages payable
Rent revenue collected one month in advance
Portion of long-term debt payable in current year

explanation: Wages payable is an accrued liability because it represents wages earned by employees but not yet paid.

text: Under PAS 37, a provision is recognized

choices.text: When there is a possible obligation arising from past event
When management decides that it is essential that a provision be made
When there is a legal obligation arising from a past event, the probability of the outflow of resources is less than probable, and a reliable estimate can be made
When there is a constructive obligation as a result of a past event, the outflow of resources is probable, and a reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation

explanation: A provision is recognized when there is a present obligation (legal or constructive), it is probable that an outflow will be required, and the amount can be reliably estimated.

text: It is an existing liability of uncertain amount or uncertain timing

choices.text: Contingent liability
Unearned income
Discount on note payable
Provision

explanation: A provision is a liability of uncertain timing or amount.

text: A provision is recognized in the balance sheet when and only when I. An enterprise has a present obligation, legal or constructive, as a result of a past event II. It is probable that an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation III. A reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation

choices.text: I, II and III
I only
II and III
II only

explanation: All three conditions must be met to recognize a provision: present obligation, probable outflow, and reliable estimate.

text: Estimated liabilities are disclosedreported in the financial statements by

choices.text: Footnote to the financial statements
Showing the amount among the liabilities but not extending to the liability total
An appropriation of retained earnings
Appropriately classifying them as regular liabilities in the balance sheet

explanation: Estimated liabilities should be classified as regular liabilities in the balance sheet, not as footnotes or appropriations.

text: A manufacturer of household appliances has potential costs due to the discovery of a defect in one of its products. The occurrence of the loss is probable, and the costs can be reasonably estimated. This present obligation should be

choices.text: This present obligation should be
Accrued and disclosed as a liability
Accrued as a liability but not disclosed
Neither accrued nor disclosed as a liability

explanation: Since the loss is probable and can be reasonably estimated, it should be both accrued and disclosed as a liability.

text: On September 1, 2021, a company borrowed cash and signed a two-year interest-bearing note on which both the principal and interest are payable on September 1, 2023. How many months of accrued interest would be included in the liability for accrued interest on December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2022? Dec. 31, 2021 Dec. 31, 2022

choices.text: 4 months 16 months
4 months 4 months
12 months 24 months

explanation: On December 31, 2021, 4 months of interest would be accrued (Sept-Dec 2021). On December 31, 2022, 16 months would be accrued (Jan-Dec 2022).

text: On September 1, 2021, a company borrowed cash and signed a one-year interest bearing on which both the principal and interest are payable on September 1, 2022. How will the note payable and the accrued interest be classified on December 31, 2021 balance sheet? Note payable Accrued interest

choices.text: Current liability Noncurrent liability
Noncurrent liability Current liability
Current liability Current liability
Noncurrent liability No entry

explanation: Both the note payable and accrued interest are current liabilities because they are due within one year from the balance sheet date.

text: A retail store received cash and issued gift certificate that is redeemable in merchandise. When the gift certificate was issued, a

choices.text: Deferred revenue account should be decreased
Deferred revenue account should be increased
Revenue account should be decreased
Revenue account should be increased

explanation: When gift certificates are issued, the cash received should be recorded as deferred revenue (a liability) until the certificates are redeemed.

text: Magazine subscriptions collected in advance are treated as

choices.text: Contra account to magazine subscriptions receivable
Deferred revenue in the liability section
Deferred revenue in the stockholders equity section
Magazine subscription refunds in the income statem ent in the period collected

explanation: Magazine subscriptions collected in advance are recorded as deferred revenue (a liability) until the magazines are delivered.

text: A company receives an advance payment for special order goods that are to be manufactured and delivered within six months. The advance payment should be reported in the companys balance sheet as a

choices.text: Deferred charge
Current liability
Contra asset account
Noncurrent liability

explanation: The advance payment should be reported as a current liability (deferred revenue) because the goods will be delivered within one year.

text: X Company is a retailer of home appliances and offers a service contract on each appliance sold. X sells appliances on installment contracts, but all service contracts must be paid in full at the time of sale. Collections received for service contracts should be recorded as an increase in a

choices.text: X sells appliances on installment contracts, but all service contracts must be paid in full at the time of sale. Collections received for service contracts should be recorded as an increase in a
Deferred revenue account
Sales contracts receivable valuation account
Stockholders equity valuation account

explanation: Collections received for service contracts should be recorded as deferred revenue until the services are performed.

text: Under a royalty agreement with another enterprise, a company will receive royalties from the assignment of a patent for four years. The royalties received in advance should be reported as revenue

choices.text: In the period received
In the period earned
Evenly over the life of the royalty agreement
At the date of the royalty agreement

explanation: Royalties received in advance should be recognized as revenue evenly over the life of the royalty agreement.

text: How would the proceeds received from the advance sale of nonrefundable tickets for a theatrical performance be reported in the sellers financial statements before the perfo rmance?

choices.text: Revenue for the entire proceeds
Revenue to the extent of related costs expended
Unearned revenue to the extent of related costs expended
Unearned revenue for the entire proceeds

explanation: The entire proceeds from advance ticket sales should be recorded as unearned revenue until the performance occurs.

text: On March 31, 2021, X Company received an advance payment of 60% of the sales price for special order goods to be manufactured and delivered within five months. At the same time, X subcontracted for production of the special-order goods at a price equal to 40% of the main contract price. What liabilities should be reported in X's March 31, 2021 balance sheet?

choices.text: None
Deferred revenue equal to 60% of the main contract price and payable to subcontractor equal to 40% of the main contract price
Deferred revenue equal to 60% of the main contract price and no payable to subcontractor
No deferred revenue but payable to subcontractor is reported at 40% of the main contract price

explanation: X should report both the deferred revenue from the advance payment and the payable to the subcontractor.

text: A liability for compensated absences, such as vacations, for which it is expected that employees will be paid, should

choices.text: Be accrued during the per iod when the compensated time is expected to be used by the employees
Be accrued during the period following the time at which an employee becomes vested for retirement benefits
Be accrued during the period when earned
Never be accrued unless a written obl igation exists

explanation: The liability for compensated absences should be accrued during the period when the employees earn the right to the benefits.

text: Where there is a continuous range of possible outcomes and each point in the range is as likely as the other, provision is measured based on

choices.text: Expected value method
Probability-weighted-method
Midpoint of the range of possible outcomes
Estimate of the individual most likely outcome

explanation: When there is a continuous range of possible outcomes and each point in the range is as likely as any other, the midpoint of the range should be used to measure the provision.

text: A contingency is described as

choices.text: An estimated liability
A potential small liability
A potentially large liability
An event which is not recognized because it is not probable that an outflow will be required, or the amount cannot be reasonably estimated

explanation: A contingency is a possible obligation that is not recognized because it is not probable or the amount cannot be reliably estimated.

text: Which of the following is the most likely candidate for a contingent liability that can be accrued?

choices.text: Warranty liability
Property tax payable
Potential liability for a lawsuit in which the firm is a def endant
Potential liability of a product still in the planning stage no items have been sold

explanation: Warranty liability is typically accrued because it is probable that an outflow will be required and the amount can be reasonably estimated.

text: Which of the following is the proper accounting treatment of a contingent asset?

choices.text: An accrued amount
Deferred earnings
An account receivable with an additional disclosure explaining the nature of the transaction
A disclosure only

explanation: Contingent assets are only disclosed in the notes to the financial statements, not recognized in the accounts.

text: Contingent assets are usually recognized when

choices.text: Realized
Occurrence is reasonably possible, and the amount can be reasonably estimated
Occurrence is probable and the amount can be reasonably estimated
The amount can be reasonably estimated

explanation: Contingent assets are only recognized when they are virtually certain to be realized.

text: On January 17, 2021, an explosion occurred at X Company plant causing extensive property damage to area buildings. Although no claims had yet been asserted against X by March 10, 2022, X's management and counsel concluded that it is likely that claims will be asserted and that it is reasonably possible X will be responsible for damages. X's management believed that P1,250,000 would be a reasonable estimate of its liability. X's P5,000,000 comprehensive public liability policy has a P250,000 deductible clause. In X's December 31, 2021 financial statements which were issued on March 25, 2022, how should this item be reported?

choices.text: As an accrued liability of P250,000
As a footnote disclosure indicating the possible loss of P250,000
As a footnote disclosure indicating the possible loss of P1,250,000
No footnote disclosure or accrual is necessary

explanation: Since the loss is only reasonably possible (not probable), it should be disclosed in the footnotes but not accrued.

text: X Company is being sued for illness caused to local residents as a result of negligence on the companys part in permitting the local residents to be exposed to highly toxic chemicals from its plant. X's lawyer states that it is probable that X will lose the suit and be found liable for a judgment costing anywhere from P500,000 to P2,500,000. However, the lawyer states that the most probable cost is P1,000,000. As a result of the above facts, X should accrue

choices.text: A loss of P500,000 and disclose an additional contingency of up to P2,000,000
A loss of P1,000,000 and disclose an additional contingency of up to P1,500,000
A loss of P1,000 but not disclose any additional contingency
No loss but disclose a contingency of P500,000 to P2,500,000

explanation: Since the loss is probable, X should accrue the most likely amount (P1,000,000) and disclose the additional possible loss up to P1,500,000.

text: A long-term debt falling due within one year should be reported as noncurrent if the following conditions are met choose the incorrect one

choices.text: The original term is for a period of more than one year
The enterprise intends to refinance the obligation on a long-term basis
The intent to refinance is supported by an agreement to refinance which is completed before the balance sheet date
The intent to refinance is supported by an agreement to refinance which is completed after the issuance of the financial statements -----

explanation: The refinancing agreement must be completed before the balance sheet date, not after the issuance of the financial statements.

text: Covenants are often attached to long-term borrowing agreements which represent undertakings by the borrower. Under these covenants, if certain conditions related to the borrower's financial position are breached, the liability becomes payable on demand. This liability can still be classified as noncurrent

choices.text: This liability can still be classified as noncurrent
When the lender has agreed before the balance sheet date not to demand payment
When it is probable that further breaches or violations will not occur within one year from balance sheet date
When the lender has agreed before the balance sheet date not to demand payment and it is probable that further breaches will not occur within one year from balance sheet date

explanation: Both conditions must be met: the lender must agree not to demand payment before the balance sheet date, and it must be probable that no further breaches will occur within one year.

text: If a long-term debt becomes callable due to the violation of a loan covenant

choices.text: Cash must be reserved to pay the debt
The debt must be reclassified as current
Retained earnings must be restricted in the amount of the debt
The debt may continue to be classified as long-term if the entity believes the covenant can be renegotiated -----

explanation: When a long-term debt becomes callable due to a covenant violation, it must be reclassified as current unless the lender has agreed not to demand payment and no further violations are expected.

text: After initial recognition, an entity shall measure a bond liability at amortized cost using the

choices.text: Effective interest method
Bond outstanding method
Straight line method
Either effective interest or straight-line method -----

explanation: After initial recognition, bonds should be measured at amortized cost using the effective interest method.

text: Bonds payable should be reported as a long-term liability in the balance sheet of the issuer at

choices.text: Current market price
Lower of cost or market
Issue price, excluding interest at purchase date
Issue price plus any unamortized bond premium or less any unamortized discount -----

explanation: Bonds payable should be reported at their carrying amount, which is the issue price plus unamortized premium or less unamortized discount.

text: When the effective-interest method is used to amortize bond premium or discount, the periodic amortization would

choices.text: Increase if the bonds were issued at a discount
Increase if the bonds were issued at a premium
Decrease if the bonds were issued at a premium
Increase if the bonds were issued at either a discount or a premium -----

explanation: When using the effective interest method, the periodic amortization increases over time for bonds issued at a discount.

text: If a bond was sold at 108, the stated rate of interest was

choices.text: Equal to market rate
Not related to market rate
Higher than market rate
Lower than market rate -----

explanation: When a bond is sold at a premium (above 100), the stated rate is higher than the market rate.

text: X Company sold and issued a P100,000, 10% bond at 99. Therefore, the bond

choices.text: Sold at a discount because the stated interest rate was lower than the market interest rate
Was sold at a premium because the stated interest rate was higher than the yield rate
Sold at a premium because the P1,000 accrued interest is added to the P100,000 face amount
Was sold for P100,000 less P1,000 of accrued interest -----

explanation: When a bond is sold at 99 (below 100), it is sold at a discount because the stated rate is lower than the market rate.

text: Which of the following is correct?

choices.text: The yield or effective interest rate on a bond is equal to the stated rate if the bond premium or discount is amortized by using the straight-line method
The terms, yield rate, stated rate, and market rate are generally interchangeable when referring to interest on bonds
Interest revenue and expense related to bonds are always computed using the stated rate of interest
If a bond is sold at its face amount, the stated and effective interest rates are the same -----

explanation: When a bond is sold at face value (par), the stated rate equals the effective rate.

text: Bond issuance costs should be

choices.text: Expensed in the period when the debt is issued
Recorded as a reduction in the carrying amount of bonds payable
Reported as an expense in the period the bonds mature or are retired
Accumulated in deferred charge account and amortized over the life of the bonds -----

explanation: Bond issuance costs should be deducted from the carrying amount of the bonds payable.

text: An investor purchased a bond as a long-term investment on January 1. Annual interest was received on December 31. The investor's interest income for the year would be lowest if the bond was purchased at

choices.text: A discount
A premium
Par
Face value -----

explanation: When a bond is purchased at a premium, the interest income is lower because the premium is amortized against the interest income.

text: An investor purchased a bond as a long-term investment on January 2. The investor's carrying value at the end of the first year would be highest if the bonds was purchased at a

choices.text: Discount and amortized by the straight-line method
Discount and amortized by the effective interest method
Premium and amortized by the straight-line method
Premium and amortized by the effective interest method -----

explanation: The carrying value would be highest when purchased at a premium and amortized using the straight-line method because this method results in slower amortization of the premium.

text: When interest payment dates of a bond are May 1 and November 1, and a bond is purchased on June 1, the amount of cash paid by the investor will be

choices.text: Decreased by accrued interest from June 1 to November 1
Decreased by accrued interest from May 1 to June 1
Increased by accrued interest from June 1 to November 1
Increased by accrued interest from May 1 to June 1 -----

explanation: The investor must pay the seller for the accrued interest from the last interest payment date (May 1) to the purchase date (June 1).

text: For bonds payable, the cash interest paid in each interest period is

choices.text: The same amount regardless of whether the bond was sold at par, a discount, or a premium
Different depending upon the date of sale
Not the same amount when the stated and yield interest rates are different
Dependent on the initial amount of accrued interest -----

explanation: The cash interest payment is always based on the stated rate and face value, regardless of whether the bond was sold at par, discount, or premium.

text: The use of the effective interest method in amortizing a premium on bonds payable would result in

choices.text: An increasing amount of interest expense and a decreasing carrying amount for the bonds payable
A decreasing amount of interest expense and an increasing carrying amount for the bonds payable
A decreasing amount of interest expense and a decreasing carrying amount for the bonds payable
An increasing amount of interest expense and an increasing carrying amount for the bonds payable -----

explanation: When amortizing a premium, both the interest expense and the carrying amount decrease over time.

text: Under the effective interest method of bond discount or premium amortization, the periodic interest expense is equal to

choices.text: The stated nominal rate of interest multiplied by the face value of the bonds
The effective yield rate of interest multiplied by the face value of the bonds
The stated rate multiplied by the beginning-of-period carrying amount of the bonds
The effective rate multiplied by the beginning-of-period carrying amount of the bonds -----

explanation: Under the effective interest method, interest expense is calculated by multiplying the effective rate by the beginning carrying amount.

text: If bonds are sold at a discount and the effective interest method of amortization is used, interest expense will

choices.text: Increase from one period to another
Remain constant from one period to another
Equal the cash interest payment each period
Be less than the cash interest payment each period -----

explanation: When bonds are sold at a discount, interest expense increases over time under the effective interest method.

text: A bond or similar instrument convertible by the holder into a fixed number of ordinary shares of the entity is

choices.text: A compound financial instrument
A derivative financial instrument
A primary financial instrument
An equity instruments -----

explanation: A convertible bond is a compound financial instrument because it contains both a liability component (the bond) and an equity component (the conversion option).

text: Which statement is incorrect regarding compound financial instruments?

choices.text: Compound instruments have both a liability and an equity component from the issuer's perspective
The component parts should be accounted for and presented separately according to their substance based on the definitions of liability and equity
The split is made at issuance and not revised for subsequent changes in market interest rates, share prices, or other event that changes the likelihood that the conversion option will be exercised

When the initial carrying amount of a compound financial instrument is required to be allocated to its equity and liability components, the liability component is assigned the residual amount after deducting from the fair value of the instrument as a whole the amount separately determined for the equity component -----

explanation: The equity component is assigned the residual amount after deducting the liability component from the fair value of the instrument as a whole.

text: Cash proceeds from the issuance of the convertible bonds should be reported as

choices.text: Contributed capital for the entire proceeds
Liability for the fair value of the bond and the balance for the portion of the proceeds attributed to the conversion feature
A liability for the face amount of the bond and contributed capital for the premium over the face amount
A liability for the entire proceeds -----

explanation: The proceeds should be split between the liability component (fair value of the bond) and the equity component (conversion feature).

text: Under PAS 32, which of the following statements about accounting for compound instrument is true? I. The issuer shall classify a compound instrument as either financial liability or equity based on the predominant characteristics of the contractual arrangement II. The issuer shall classify the liability or equity components of a compound instrument separately as financial liability and equity components

choices.text: I only
II only
Both I and II
Neither I nor II -----

explanation: Under PAS 32, the issuer must classify the components of a compound instrument separately as liability and equity components.

text: When bonds are issued with detachable warrants, what amount is recorded as share premium?

choices.text: Zero
The market value of the warrants
The excess of the proceeds over the fair value of the bonds
The excess of the proceeds over the face value of the bonds -----

explanation: The amount allocated to the warrants (share premium) is the excess of the total proceeds over the fair value of the bonds without the warrants.

text: When bonds are converted into ordinary share, the ordinary share is recorded at the carrying value of the bonds and

choices.text: Gains resulting from the transaction are recognized but losses are not recognized
Losses resulting from the transaction are recognized but losses are not recognized
Both losses and gains resulting from the transaction are recognized
Neither gains or losses resulting from the transaction are recognized -----

explanation: When bonds are converted into shares, no gain or loss is recognized. The shares are recorded at the carrying value of the bonds.

text: There is substantial modification of terms of an old financial liability if the gain or loss on extinguishment is

choices.text: At least 10% of the old liability
Less than 10% of the old liability
At least 10% of the new liability
Less than 10% of the new liability -----

explanation: A modification is considered substantial if the gain or loss on extinguishment is at least 10% of the old liability.

text: For a troubled debt restructuring involving only a modification of terms, which of the following specified by the new terms would be compared to the carrying amount of the debt to determine if a gain should be recognized?

choices.text: The total future cash payments
The present value of the debt at the original interest rate
The present value of the debt at the modified interest rate
The amount of future cash payments designated as principal -----

explanation: For a troubled debt restructuring with only a modification of terms, the total future cash payments are compared to the carrying amount to determine if a gain should be recognized.

text: The lessee may apply the operating lease model under what condition?

choices.text: Short-term lease
Low value lease
Both short-term lease and low value lease
Under all circumstances -----

explanation: Under IFRS 16, a lessee may apply the operating lease model for both short-term leases and leases of low-value assets.

text: A short-term lease is defined as

choices.text: Twelve months or less
Six months or less
Twelve-month lease with a purchase option
Two-year lease with option to terminate -----

explanation: A short-term lease is defined as a lease that, at the commencement date, has a lease term of 12 months or less.

text: Which statement is true about low value lease?

choices.text: The value of an underlying asset is based on the value of the asset when new regardless of the age of the asset
The term of a low value lease may be more than twelve months
An underlying asset does not qualify as low value lease if the nature of the asset is such that the asset is typically not of low value when new
All of these statements are true about low value lease -----

explanation: All the statements are correct regarding low value leases. The value is based on the new asset value, the term can be more than 12 months, and the nature of the asset is considered.

text: Under IFRS 16, a lessee is required to account for all leases as finance lease and recognize

choices.text: Right of use asset and lease liability
Right of use asset but not lease liability
Lease liability but not right of use asset
Neither right of use asset nor lease liability -----

explanation: Under IFRS 16, lessees must recognize both a right-of-use asset and a lease liability for all leases (except short-term and low-value leases).

text: The cost of right of use asset comprises all, except

choices.text: The present value of lease payments
Lease payment made to lessor on or before commencement date
Initial direct cost incurred by lessee
Estimated cost of dismantling and restoring the underlying asset for which the lease has no present obligation -----

explanation: The cost of the right-of-use asset does not include estimated costs for which the lessee has no present obligation.

text: What is the cost basis of an asset acquired by a lease which is in substance an installment purchase?

choices.text: The net realizable value of the asset determined at the date of the lease agreement plus the sum of the future minimum lease payments under the lease
The sum of the future minimum lease payments under the lease
The present value of the amount of the future minimum lease payments under the lease discounted at an appropriate rate
The present value of the market price of the asset discounted at an appropriate rate as an amount to be received at the end of the lease -----

explanation: The cost basis of a leased asset is the present value of the minimum lease payments discounted at the appropriate rate.

text: Under PFRS 16, minimum lease payments may include

choices.text: Bargain purchase option
Guaranteed residual value
Periodic rental payments
Any of these -----

explanation: Minimum lease payments include periodic rental payments, guaranteed residual value, and bargain purchase option.

text: The interest rate implicit in the lease is the discount rate that causes the aggregate of the present value of the minimum lease payments and the unguaranteed residual value to be equal to the

choices.text: Fair value of the lease asset
Fair value of the lease asset and initial direct costs of the lessor
Fair value of the lease asset and initial direct costs of the lessee
Gross investment in the lease -----

explanation: The interest rate implicit in the lease is the rate that makes the present value of lease payments and unguaranteed residual value equal to the fair value of the asset plus lessor's initial direct costs.

text: In computing depreciation of a right of use asset, the lessee should subtract

choices.text: A guaranteed residual value and depreciate over the life of the asset
A guaranteed residual and depreciate over the term of the lease
An unguaranteed residual value and depreciate over the life of the asset
An unguaranteed residual value and depreciate over the term of the lease -----

explanation: The right-of-use asset should be depreciated over the lease term, subtracting any guaranteed residual value.

text: The concept that is principally used to classify leases into operating and finance from the point of view of the lessor is

choices.text: Completeness
Neutrality
Prudence
Substance over form -----

explanation: The classification of leases is based on the substance over form principle, looking at the economic reality of the transaction rather than its legal form.

text: The classification of a lease from the point of view of the lessor is normally carried out

choices.text: At the end of the lease term
At the inception of the lease
When the entity deems it necessary
After a cooling off period of one year -----

explanation: Lease classification should be made at the inception of the lease and should not be changed unless the lease terms are modified.

text: The basic accounting issue for a lessor is

choices.text: Revenue recognition during the lease term
Expense recognition during the lease term
Computing depreciation over the lease term
Determination of the cost of the leased asset -----

explanation: The main accounting issue for lessors is determining how to recognize revenue over the lease term.

text: Under PFRS 16, lessors are required to account for lease receipts from operation leases as

choices.text: Revenue, at the end of the lease term
Income, on inception date of the lease
Income, on a straight-line basis over the lease term
Revenue, on a reducing balance basis over the lease term -----

explanation: Operating lease receipts should be recognized as income on a straight-line basis over the lease term.

text: When should a lessor recognize in income a nonrefundable lease bonus paid by a lessee in an operating lease?

choices.text: When received
At the inception of the lease
At the lease expiration
Over the lease term -----

explanation: Nonrefundable lease bonuses should be recognized as income over the lease term on a straight-line basis.

text: As an inducement to enter a lease, a lessor granted a lessee 12 months of free rental under a 5-year operating lease. The lease was effective on January 1, 2020 and provides for monthly rental payments to begin January 1, 2021. The lessee made the first rental payments on December 31, 2020. In its 2020 income statement, the lessor should report rental revenue in an amount equal to

choices.text: Zero
Cash received during 2020
One-fifth of the total cash to be received over the life of the lease
One-fourth of the total cash to be received over the life of the lease -----

explanation: The total rental income should be recognized on a straight-line basis over the 5-year lease term, regardless of when payments are received.

text: Which of the following is a correct statement of one of the lease capitalization criteria from the point of view of the lessor?

choices.text: The lease contains a purchase option
The lease transfers ownership of the property to the lessor
The lease term is equal to or more than 75% of the economic life of the property
The minimum lease payments equal or exceed 90% of the fair value of the property -----

explanation: This is one of the criteria for classifying a lease as a finance lease from the lessor's perspective.

text: Which is the correct accounting treatment for a finance lease in the accounts of a lessor?

choices.text: Treat as a noncurrent asset equal to net investment in lease. Recognize all finance payments in income statement
Treat as a receivable equal to gross amount receivable on lease. Recognize finance payments in cash by reducing debt
Treat as a receivable equal to net investment in the lease. Recognize finance payment by reducing debt and taking interest to income statement
Treat as a receivable equal to net investment in the lease. Recognize finance payments in cash by reduction debt -----

explanation: For a finance lease, the lessor records a receivable at the net investment amount and recognizes interest income over the lease term.

text: Which of the following statements in relation to initial direct costs is correct?

choices.text: In a direct financing lease, initial direct costs are added to the net investment in the lease
In a sales-type lease, initial direct costs are expensed in the year of incurrence
For operating lease, initial direct costs are deferred and allocated over the lease term
All of the statements are correct -----

explanation: All statements are correct regarding the treatment of initial direct costs in different types of leases.

text: Which of the following statements characterizes a sales type lease?

choices.text: The lessor recognizes only interest revenue over the life of the asset
The lessor recognizes only interest revenue over the lease term
The lessor recognizes a dealer's profit at lease inception and interest revenue over the lease term
The lessor recognizes a dealer's profit at lease inception and interest revenue over the asset life -----

explanation: In a sales-type lease, the lessor recognizes a dealer's profit at the start of the lease and interest revenue over the lease term.

text: Under a sales-type lease

choices.text: The sale price includes the present value of the unguaranteed residual value
The gross profit is the same whether the residual value is guaranteed or unguaranteed
The present value of guaranteed residual is deducted to determine the cost of goods sold
None of these -----

explanation: None of the statements are correct regarding sales-type leases. The sale price excludes unguaranteed residual value, gross profit differs based on residual value guarantee, and guaranteed residual value is not deducted from cost of goods sold.

text: Gross investment in the lease is the

choices.text: Aggregate of the minimum lease payments under a finance lease of the lessor and any unguaranteed residual value accruing to the lessor
The minimum lease payments under a finance lease of the lessor
Present value of minimum lease payments under a finance lease of the lessor and any unguaranteed residual value
Present value of the minimum lease payments under a finance lease of the lessor -----

explanation: Gross investment in the lease includes both minimum lease payments and any unguaranteed residual value accruing to the lessor.

text: Which of the following would not be included in the lease receivable account?

choices.text: A bargain purchase option
Guaranteed residual value
Unguaranteed residual value
All would be included -----

explanation: Unguaranteed residual value is not included in the lease receivable account as it is not guaranteed to be received.

text: Which of the following statements characterizes lessor accounting for residual values?

choices.text: Guaranteed residual values are included in the gross investment amount, but unguaranteed residual values are excluded from the gross investment
Unguaranteed residual values are included in the gross investment amount, but guaranteed residual values are excluded from the gross investment
Guaranteed residual values and unguaranteed residual values are excluded from the gross investment
Guaranteed residual values and unguaranteed residual values are included in the gross investment -----

explanation: Both guaranteed and unguaranteed residual values are included in the gross investment in the lease.

text: Under a finance lease that includes a bargain purchase option, how is depreciation on the asset under lease recognized by Lessor Lessee

choices.text: Not recognized Depreciate over lease term
Not recognized Depreciate over remaining life
Depreciate over remaining life Depreciate over remaining life
Depreciate over remaining life Not recognized -----

explanation: The lessor does not depreciate the asset as it is transferred to the lessee, while the lessee depreciates it over its remaining useful life.

text: In a sale and leaseback arrangement, the lessee is also

choices.text: The new owner of the property
The buyer
The seller
A third-party guarantor -----

explanation: In a sale and leaseback transaction, the lessee is the original owner who sells the asset and then leases it back.

text: The lessor must classify a sale-and-leaseback arrangement as an

choices.text: Operating lease or a finance lease
Operating lease or a sales-type lease
Direct financing lease or an operating lease
Direct financing lease or a sales-type lease -----

explanation: In a sale and leaseback arrangement, the lessor must classify the lease as either an operating lease or a finance lease.

text: A lease transaction that involves the sale of an asset that is then leased back to the seller for all or part of its remaining economic life is known as

choices.text: A direct financing lease
A sales-type lease
A sale and leaseback
A leveraged lease -----

explanation: A sale and leaseback transaction occurs when an entity sells an asset and then leases it back from the buyer.

text: The objective of accounting for income taxes is

choices.text: Objectivity in the calculation of periodic expense
Recognition of assets and liabilities
Proper matching of periodic expense to periodic revenue
Consistency of tax expense measurement with tax planning strategies -----

explanation: The primary objective of accounting for income taxes is to recognize the tax consequences of transactions and events in the financial statements, which involves recognizing deferred tax assets and liabilities.

text: It is the profit for a period determined in accordance with the rules established by taxation authorities upon which income taxes are payable

choices.text: Accounting profit
Taxable profit
Net profit
Accounting profit before tax -----

explanation: Taxable profit is the amount of profit determined in accordance with tax laws and regulations, upon which income taxes are payable.

text: It is the amount of income taxes payable in respect of taxable profit

choices.text: Current tax expense
Tax expense
Deferred tax expense
Deferred tax benefit -----

explanation: Current tax expense is the amount of income taxes payable in respect of the taxable profit for the current period.

text: Taxable income of a corporation

choices.text: Is reported on the income statement
Is based on international financial reporting standards
Differs from accounting income due to differences in inter-period allocation between the two methods of income determination
Differs from accounting income due to differences in inter-period allocation and permanent differences between the two methods of income determination -----

explanation: Taxable income differs from accounting income due to both temporary differences (inter-period allocation) and permanent differences between tax and accounting rules.

text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Temporary differences occur because accounting standards and income tax laws differ as to when they recognize assets, liabilities, owners equity, revenues, gains, expenses and losses
The term future taxable amounts relates to a deferred tax asset
Future taxable amounts include revenues and gains that are included in the tax return before they are recognized for accounting purposes
Future deductible amounts include expenses and losses that are included in the tax return before they are recognized for accounting purposes -----

explanation: Temporary differences arise due to timing differences between when items are recognized for accounting purposes versus tax purposes.

text: Intra-period tax allocation

choices.text: Involves the allocation of income taxes between current and future periods
Associates tax effect with different items in the income statement
Arises because certain revenue and expenses appear in the financial statements either before or after they are included in the income tax return
Arises because different income statement items are taxed at different rates -----

explanation: Intra-period tax allocation involves allocating the total tax expense to different components of the income statement (continuing operations, discontinued operations, other comprehensive income).

text: This is the recognition of a deferred tax asset or deferred tax liability

choices.text: Intra-period tax allocation
Inter-period tax allocation
None of the above
All of the above -----

explanation: Inter-period tax allocation involves recognizing deferred tax assets and liabilities to account for temporary differences between accounting and taxable income.

text: Differences between taxable income and pretax accounting income arising from transactions that, under applicable tax laws and regulations, will not be offset by corresponding differences or turn around in future periods is a definition of

choices.text: Temporary differences
Permanent differences
Deductible differences
Taxable differences -----

explanation: Permanent differences are differences between taxable income and accounting income that will never reverse in future periods.

text: These are differences between carrying amount of an asset or liability in the statement of financial position and its tax base

choices.text: Temporary differences
Timing differences
Permanent differences
Accounting differences -----

explanation: Temporary differences are differences between the carrying amount of an asset or liability in the financial statements and its tax base.

text: A pretax income always results when

choices.text: Revenues exceed operating expenses
Revenues exceed the cost of goods sold
The gross margin exceeds operating expenses
The cost of goods sold exceeds operating expenses -----

explanation: Pretax income is the result when total revenues exceed total operating expenses, regardless of the cost of goods sold.

text: The deferred tax consequence attributable to a deductible temporary difference and operating loss carry forward is known as

choices.text: Current tax
Deferred tax asset
Deferred tax expense
Deferred tax liability -----

explanation: A deferred tax asset arises from deductible temporary differences and operating loss carryforwards that will result in future tax benefits.

text: How do you call a taxable temporary difference?

choices.text: Current tax asset
Current tax liability
Deferred tax asset
Deferred tax liability -----

explanation: A taxable temporary difference results in a deferred tax liability because it will lead to higher taxable income in future periods.

text: Which of the following differences would result in future taxable amounts?

choices.text: Revenues or gains that are taxable before they are recognized in financial income
Expenses or losses that are deductible after they are recognized in financial income
Expenses or losses that are deductible before they are recognized in financial income
Revenues or gains that are recognized in financial income but are never included in taxable income -----

explanation: When expenses or losses are recognized in financial income before they are deductible for tax purposes, this creates a taxable temporary difference that will result in future taxable amounts.

text: The deferred tax expense is the

choices.text: Decrease in balance of deferred tax asset minus the increase in balance of deferred tax liability
Increase in balance of deferred tax asset plus the increase in balance of deferred tax liability
Increase in balance of deferred tax asset minus the increase in balance of deferred tax liability
Increase in balance of deferred tax liability minus the increase in balance of deferred tax asset -----

explanation: Deferred tax expense is calculated as the increase in deferred tax liability minus the increase in deferred tax asset during the period.

text: Current tax expense plus deferred tax expense is

choices.text: A meaningless sum
Income tax expense
Tax deductible expense
None of these -----

explanation: Total income tax expense is the sum of current tax expense and deferred tax expense.

text: Total tax expense is based on

choices.text: Taxable income
Financial income
Financial income excluding temporary and permanent differences
Financial income excluding permanent differences but including temporary differences -----

explanation: Total tax expense is based on financial income, which is then adjusted for permanent and temporary differences to arrive at taxable income.

text: According to PAS 12, deferred tax assets and liabilities should be reported in the balance sheet

choices.text: As noncurrent asset and noncurrent liability
Always net noncurrent asset or net noncurrent liability
As current and noncurrent depending on the order of liquidity or maturity
As current and noncurrent assets and liabilities depending on the balance sheet classification of the related tax basis of the temporary difference -----

explanation: PAS 12 requires that deferred tax assets and liabilities be presented as noncurrent items and be offset to show a net noncurrent asset or liability.

text: X Company's financial reporting basis of its plant assets exceeded the tax basis because it uses a different method of reporting depreciation for financial reporting purpose and tax purposes. If there is no other temporary differences, X should report a

choices.text: Current tax asset
Current tax payable
Deferred tax asset
Deferred tax liability -----

explanation: When the financial reporting basis exceeds the tax basis, it creates a taxable temporary difference that results in a deferred tax liability.

text: A temporary difference that would result in a deferred tax asset is

choices.text: Accrued warranty expense
Accrual commission income
Interest revenue on government bonds
Excess of tax depreciation over financial accounting depreciation -----

explanation: Accrued warranty expense creates a deductible temporary difference because it is recognized in financial income before it is deductible for tax purposes.

text: All of the following would result in a deferred tax asset, except

choices.text: The tax base of an asset is greater than carrying amount
Interest expense is accrued but included in taxable income on a cash basis
The financial accumulated depreciation is greater than tax accumulated depreciation
Development costs have been capitalized and amortized but were included in determining taxable income in the period incurred -----

explanation: When financial depreciation exceeds tax depreciation, it creates a taxable temporary difference that results in a deferred tax liability, not a deferred tax asset.

text: A temporary difference which would result in a deferred tax liability is

choices.text: Accrual of estimated litigation loss
Accrual of estimated warranty cost
Subscription received in advance
An installment sale which is included in accounting income at the time of sale and included in taxable income when collected -----

explanation: This creates a taxable temporary difference because the revenue is recognized in financial income before it is included in taxable income.

text: Which temporary difference would result in a deferred tax asset?

choices.text: Tax penalty or surcharge
Dividend received on share investment
Excess tax depreciation over accounting depreciation
Rent received in advance included in taxable income but deferred for financial accounting -----

explanation: This creates a deductible temporary difference because the revenue is included in taxable income before it is recognized in financial income.

text: Under PAS 12, which temporary difference would result in a deferred tax liability?

choices.text: Accrual of warranty expense
Interest revenue on municipal bonds
Subscription revenue received in advance
Excess tax depreciation over financial depreciation -----

explanation: When tax depreciation exceeds financial depreciation, it creates a taxable temporary difference that results in a deferred tax liability.

text: When accounting for income taxes, a temporary difference occurs when

choices.text: An item is included in the calculation of net income in one year and taxable income in a different year
An item is included in the calculation of net income but is neither taxable nor deductible
The accrual method of accounting is used
An item is no longer taxable due to a change in the tax law -----

explanation: Temporary differences arise when there is a timing difference between when an item is recognized in financial income versus taxable income.

text: All of the following would result to deferred tax asset, except

choices.text: Interest expense is accrued but included in taxable income on a cash basis
The accumulated depreciation on an asset is greater than accumulated tax depreciation
Development costs have been capitalized and amortized but were deducted in determining taxable income in the period incurred
The tax base for a machine is greater than the carrying amount -----

explanation: When financial depreciation exceeds tax depreciation, it creates a taxable temporary difference that results in a deferred tax liability, not a deferred tax asset.

text: An entity shall offset a deferred tax asset and deferred tax liability when I. The deferred tax asset and deferred tax liability relate to income taxes levied by the same taxing authority II. The entity has a legal enforceable right to offset a current tax asset against a current tax liability

choices.text: I only
II only
Both I and II
Neither I nor II -----

explanation: Deferred tax assets and liabilities can be offset only if they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxing authority. The second condition applies to current tax assets and liabilities, not deferred tax items.

text: In a defined contribution plan, a formula is used that

choices.text: Defines the benefits that the employee will receive at the time of retirement
Ensures that pension expense and the cash funding amount will be different
Requires an employer to contribute a certain sum each period based on the formula
Ensures that employers are at risk to make sure funds are available at retirement -----

explanation: In a defined contribution plan, the employer's obligation is limited to making specified contributions to the plan, and the benefits received by employees depend on the performance of the plan assets.

text: In a defined benefit plan, a formula is used that

choices.text: Requires that the benefit of gain or the risk of loss from the assets contributed to the pension plan be borne by the employee
Defines the benefits that the employee will receive at the time of retirement
Requires that pension expense and the cash funding amount be the same
Defines the contribution the employer is to make and no promise is made concerning the ultimate benefits to be paid out to the employees -----

explanation: In a defined benefit plan, the employer promises to pay specified benefits to employees upon retirement, and the employer bears the risk of ensuring sufficient funds are available.

text: In a defined benefit plan, the process of funding refers to

choices.text: Determining the projected benefit obligation
Determining the accumulated benefit obligation
Determining the amount that might be reported for pension expense
Making the periodic contributions to a funding agency to ensure that funds are available to meet claims of retirees -----

explanation: Funding refers to the actual cash contributions made to the pension plan to ensure there are sufficient assets to pay future benefits.

text: Which of the following methods is used in PFRS to account for defined benefit pension plans?

choices.text: Accumulated benefits method
Benefit-years-of-service method
Projected-unit-credit method
Vested years of service method -----

explanation: The projected unit credit method is the actuarial cost method required by PFRS for measuring the defined benefit obligation.

text: Defined benefit cost includes service cost, net interest and remeasurement of defined benefit plan. Remeasurements of defined benefit plan include

choices.text: The difference between actual return and interest income on plan assets
Actuarial gain or loss on projected benefit obligation
Change in the effect of asset ceiling minus interest expense on the beginning effect of asset ceiling
All of these are included in remeasurements of defined benefit plan -----

explanation: Remeasurements include all of these components: actuarial gains and losses, the difference between actual and expected returns on plan assets, and changes in the effect of the asset ceiling.

text: Remeasurement of the net defined benefit liability shall be composed of

choices.text: Actuarial gains and losses
Return on plan assets, excluding amounts included in the net interest
Any change in the effect of the asset ceiling, excluding amount included in the net interest
All of the choices -----

explanation: Remeasurement of the net defined benefit liability includes all of these components: actuarial gains and losses, return on plan assets (excluding net interest), and changes in the effect of the asset ceiling.

text: Which measure requires the use of future salaries in the computation of pension obligation?

choices.text: Accumulated benefit obligation
Defined benefit obligation
Restructured benefit obligation
Vested benefit obligation -----

explanation: The defined benefit obligation (also called projected benefit obligation) includes future salary increases in its calculation, unlike the accumulated benefit obligation which uses current salary levels.

text: The interest on the defined benefit obligation component of pension expense

choices.text: Is the same as the expected return on plan assets
May be stated implicitly or explicitly when reported
Reflects the incremental borrowing rate of the employer
Reflects the rate at which pension benefits could be effectively settled -----

explanation: The interest cost component reflects the time value of money and is based on the discount rate used to measure the defined benefit obligation.

text: A pension liability would result at the end of the year if the

choices.text: Amount of employer contribution exceeds the pension expense
Fair value of the plan assets exceeds the projected benefit obligation
Projected benefit obligation exceeds the fair value of the plan assets
Amount of pension expense exceeds the amount of employer contribution -----

explanation: A pension liability exists when the projected benefit obligation (the present value of future benefits) exceeds the fair value of plan assets.

text: When the fair value of plan assets exceeds the defined benefit obligation, PAS 19R

choices.text: Requires recognition of an asset
Does not permit recognition of an asset
Recommends but does not require recognition of an asset
Requires recognition of an asset if the excess fair value of plan assets exceeds the corridor amount -----

explanation: PAS 19R requires recognition of a net defined benefit asset when the fair value of plan assets exceeds the defined benefit obligation.

text: Which is not included in service cost?

choices.text: Current service cost
Interest cost
Past service cost
Plan settlement gain or loss -----

explanation: Service cost includes current service cost, past service cost, and plan settlement gains or losses, but does not include interest cost, which is a separate component of defined benefit cost.

text: Plan assets include

choices.text: Only assets reported as pension fund
Plan assets still under the control of the entity
Contributions made by the employer and contributions made by the employee when a contributory plan is involved
None of these -----

explanation: Plan assets are assets held by a long-term employee benefit fund and do not include assets held by the employer or contributions that have not been transferred to the fund.

text: The report of a defined benefit plan shall contain I. A statement showing net assets available for benefits, the present value of promised benefits and the resulting excess or deficit II. A statement of net assets available for benefits including a note disclosing the present value of promised benefits

choices.text: I only
II only
Both I and II
Either I or II -----

explanation: The report should include a statement of net assets available for benefits with a note disclosing the present value of promised benefits, not a combined statement showing the excess or deficit.

text: According to PAS 19, Employee benefits, which of the following terms best describes other long-term employee benefits?

choices.text: Benefits which are payable after completion of employment
Benefits which fall due within twelve months of the end of the period in which the service is rendered
Benefits not falling due wholly within twelve months of the end of the period in which the service is rendered
Benefits payable as a result of an entity's decision to end an employment before the normal retirement care -----

explanation: Other long-term employee benefits are benefits that are not expected to be settled wholly within twelve months after the end of the period in which the employees render the related service.

text: Under PAS 19R, which of the following terms best describes benefits which are payable as a result of an entity's decision to end an employee's employment before the normal retirement date?

choices.text: Defined benefit plans
Post-employment benefits
Retrenchment benefits
Termination benefits -----

explanation: Termination benefits are benefits payable as a result of an entity's decision to terminate an employee's employment before the normal retirement date.

text: The component of defined benefit cost includes all of the following, except

choices.text: Plan contributions
Net interest
Remeasurements
Service cost -----

explanation: Defined benefit cost includes service cost, net interest, and remeasurements, but does not include plan contributions, which are the actual cash payments made to the plan.

text: Which of the following components of the annual pension costs shall be recognized in the other comprehensive income rather than in profit or loss?

choices.text: Service cost
Net interest on the net defined benefit liability
Remeasurements of the net defined benefit liability
All of these items are required to be recognized in this profit or loss -----

explanation: Remeasurements of the net defined benefit liability are recognized in other comprehensive income, while service cost and net interest are recognized in profit or loss.

text: The vested benefits of an employee in a pension plan represent

choices.text: Benefits to be paid to the retired employee in the subsequent year
Benefits accumulated in the hands of an independent trustee
Benefits to be paid to the retired employee in the current year
Benefits that are not contingent on the employee's continuing in service -----

explanation: Vested benefits are those that the employee is entitled to receive regardless of whether they continue working for the employer.

text: One characteristic of a corporation is

choices.text: Unlimited liability of its owners
Dissolution upon the death of an owner
The ease with which ownership is transferred
Shareholders acting as automatic corporate agents -----

explanation: One of the key characteristics of a corporation is the ease of transferability of ownership through the buying and selling of shares, unlike partnerships where ownership transfer is more restricted.

text: Shareholders are said to be the residual owners which means that the shareholders

choices.text: Are entitled to a dividend every year in which the business earns a profit
Have the rights to specific assets of the business
Bear the ultimate risks and uncertainties and receive the benefits of ownership
Can negotiate individual contracts on behalf of the entity -----

explanation: Shareholders are residual owners because they bear the ultimate risks of the business and are entitled to the remaining assets after all other claims (creditors, employees, etc.) have been satisfied.

text: Which of the following should be reported for capital stock?

choices.text: The shares authorized
The shares issued
The shares outstanding
All of these -----

explanation: All of these share amounts (authorized, issued, and outstanding) should be reported for capital stock as they provide important information about the corporation's capital structure.

text: Contributed capital consists of the following major components

choices.text: Legal and stated capital
Retained earnings and legal capital
Additional paid in capital and retained earnings
Legal capital and additional paid in capital -----

explanation: Contributed capital consists of legal capital (par or stated value of shares) and additional paid-in capital (amounts paid in excess of par or stated value).

text: Transaction costs that are directly attributable to the issuance of new shares should be

choices.text: Charged to expenses
Expensed immediately
Charged to retained earnings
Deducted from share premium -----

explanation: Transaction costs directly attributable to the issuance of new shares should be deducted from share premium (additional paid-in capital) as they reduce the net proceeds from the share issuance.

text: Cash dividends are paid on the basis of the number of shares

choices.text: Authorized
Issued
Outstanding
Outstanding less the number of treasury shares -----

explanation: Cash dividends are paid on the basis of outstanding shares, which are the shares issued and held by shareholders (excluding treasury shares).

text: It is an equity instrument that is subordinate to all other classes of equity instrument, yet carries the most rights

choices.text: Options
Ordinary share
Potential ordinary share
Warrants -----

explanation: Ordinary shares are the most basic form of equity instrument that carries voting rights and rights to residual assets, but is subordinate to all other classes of equity instruments.

text: The features frequently associated with preference shares include all of the following, except

choices.text: Nonvoting
Convertible into ordinary shares
Callable at the option of the shareholders
Preference as to assets in the event of liquidation -----

explanation: Preference shares are typically callable at the option of the corporation, not the shareholders. The other features (nonvoting, convertible, and preference in liquidation) are common features of preference shares.

text: Which feature makes a preference share more like debt than an equity instrument?

choices.text: Noncumulative
Participating
Redeemable
Voting -----

explanation: Redeemable preference shares are more like debt because they have a fixed maturity date when the corporation must repurchase the shares, similar to debt repayment.

text: How should the excess of the subscription price over the par value of common stock subscribed be recorded?

choices.text: As APIC when the subscription is received
As APIC when the subscription is collected
As Retained Earnings when the subscription is received
As APIC when the capital stock is issued -----

explanation: The excess of subscription price over par value should be recorded as additional paid-in capital (APIC) when the subscription is collected, not when it is received or when the stock is issued.

text: Preference share that has the most restrictive feature is

choices.text: Fully participating, nonvoting
Nonparticipating, cumulative, nonvoting
Noncumulative, nonparticipating, nonvoting
Noncumulative, fully participating, nonvoting -----

explanation: This type of preference share has the most restrictive features as it has no voting rights, no right to participate in additional dividends, and no right to receive unpaid dividends from previous years.

text: When shares are issued for services received, the measure should be the

choices.text: Book value of shares issued
Fair value of shares issued
Fair value of such services
Par value of shares issued -----

explanation: When shares are issued for services, the transaction should be measured at the fair value of the shares issued, as this represents the value of the consideration received.

text: Common shares issued would exceed common shares outstanding as a result of

choices.text: Declaration of a stock dividend
Declaration of stock split
Purchase of treasury stock
Payment in full of subscribed stock -----

explanation: When a corporation purchases its own shares (treasury stock), the number of outstanding shares decreases while the number of issued shares remains the same, causing issued shares to exceed outstanding shares.

text: How should a corporation reflect treasury stock on its balance sheet?

choices.text: As part of its assets
As a deduction in the stockholders equity section
As additional paid in capital
As additional shares of capital stock -----

explanation: Treasury stock should be shown as a deduction from total stockholders' equity, not as an asset or as additional paid-in capital.

text: Any loss incurred from the sale of treasury shares shall be charged to

choices.text: Loss on sale of treasury shares to be reported as other expense
Retained earnings and then share premium from treasury shares
Share premium from treasury shares and then retained earnings
Share premium from original issuance, share premium from treasury shares and then retained earnings -----

explanation: Losses from the sale of treasury shares should be charged first to any share premium from the original issuance, then to any share premium from treasury shares, and finally to retained earnings.

text: Which of the following best describes the net effect on retained earnings of the purchase and subsequent sale of treasury stock?

choices.text: Retained earnings may never be increased or decreased
Retained earnings may never be increased but sometimes decreased
Retained earnings may never be decreased but sometimes increased
Retained earnings is always affected unless the reissue price is exactly equal to cost -----

explanation: Retained earnings can be decreased by losses on the sale of treasury stock, but cannot be increased by gains on such sales (gains are credited to share premium).

text: At the date of declaration of a small ordinary share dividend, the entry should not include

choices.text: A debit to retained earnings
A credit to share dividend payable
A credit to share premium
All of these are acceptable -----

explanation: For a small share dividend, the entry should include a debit to retained earnings and a credit to share premium, but not a credit to share dividend payable (which is used for cash dividends).

text: The peso amount of total shareholders equity remains the same when there is

choices.text: Declaration of a stock dividend
Declaration of a cash dividend
Issuance of preferred stock in exchange for convertible debentures
Issuance of nonconvertible bonds with detachable stock purchase warrants -----

explanation: A stock dividend merely transfers value from retained earnings to paid-in capital, leaving total shareholders' equity unchanged.

text: The declaration of a 10 stock dividend

choices.text: Would decrease both accumulated profits and total shareholders equity
Would decrease accumulated profits but would have no effect on total shareholders total
Would have no effect on accumulated profits but would decrease total shareholders equity
Would have no effect both on accumulated profits and total shareholders equity -----

explanation: A stock dividend decreases retained earnings (accumulated profits) but increases paid-in capital by the same amount, leaving total shareholders' equity unchanged.

text: At what amount per share should retained earnings be reduced for a 20 stock dividend?

choices.text: Zero
Par value
Market value at the date of issuance
Market value at the date of declaration -----

explanation: For a stock dividend, retained earnings should be reduced at the market value per share at the date of declaration, not at par value or at the date of issuance.

text: How is an increase in the number of shares as a result of a stock split recorded?

choices.text: The transaction may be recorded by a memorandum notation in the general journal
The transaction may be recorded by a memorandum notation in the common stock account
The transaction may be recorded by a memorandum notation in the general journal and in the common stock account
There will be a transfer from the retained earnings account to the common stock account, the amount of which is equal to the par value of the new number of shares resulting from the stock split -----

explanation: A stock split requires only a memorandum entry to record the increase in the number of shares and decrease in par value, with no actual journal entry needed.

text: When a corporation declares dividend which is considered a return of the stockholders original investments, such dividend is called

choices.text: Cash dividend
Scrip dividend
Liquidating dividend
Participating dividend -----

explanation: A liquidating dividend is a distribution that represents a return of the stockholders' original investment rather than a distribution of earnings.

text: The balance in the retained earnings account is affected by the transfer to that account of I. Issued share capital II. Dividends paid or provided for III. Transfers to or from Other reserve accounts IV. Changes in accounting policies and errors V. Interest paid to debenture holders

choices.text: I, II and III only
II, III and IV only
I, II, III and IV only
II, III and V only -----

explanation: Retained earnings is affected by dividends, transfers to/from other reserves, and changes in accounting policies and errors, but not by issued share capital or interest paid to debenture holders.

text: Companies that carry no insurance against insurable casualty loss sometimes use an account called reserved for self-insurance. In preparing a balance sheet, this account should be reported as

choices.text: Appropriated retained earnings
Deferred credit
Liability
Unappropriated retained earnings -----

explanation: A reserve for self-insurance represents an appropriation of retained earnings, not a liability or deferred credit.

text: A restriction of retained earnings is most likely to be required by the

choices.text: Purchase of treasury stock
Amortization of past service cost
Payment of last maturing series of a serial bond issue
Exhaustion of potential benefits of the investment credit -----

explanation: The purchase of treasury stock may require a restriction of retained earnings to prevent the corporation from paying dividends that would impair its capital.

text: Which of the following regarding the conversion of preferred stock into common stock is true?

choices.text: Gains resulting from a conversion are recognized and losses resulting from a conversion are not recognized
Losses resulting from a conversion are recognized and gains resulting from a conversion are not recognized
Both gains and losses from a conversion are recognized
No gain or loss resulting from a conversion are recognized -----

explanation: No gain or loss is recognized when preferred stock is converted into common stock, as this is considered a transaction between equity accounts.

text: Donated capital is recorded

choices.text: As an accounting gain in the period it is received
As an accounting loss in the period it is received
At its fair market value in the period it is received
As an increase in legal capital in the period it is received -----

explanation: Donated capital should be recorded at its fair market value when received, as this represents the value of the contribution to the corporation.

text: The distribution of share rights to existing ordinary shareholders would increase share premium at

choices.text: Date of issuance of rights
Date of exercise of rights
Date of expiration of rights
All of these are correct choice -----

explanation: Share premium increases when the rights are exercised and new shares are issued, not at the date of issuance or expiration of the rights.

text: Under IFRIC 17, a property dividend declared before the end of the reporting period should be recognized as liability at the end of the reporting period at

choices.text: Carrying amount of the asset to be distributed
Fair value of the asset on the date of declaration
Fair value of the asset at the end of reporting period
Fair value of the asset at the date of distribution -----

explanation: Under IFRIC 17, a property dividend liability should be measured at the fair value of the asset to be distributed at the end of the reporting period.

text: Which of the following statements about property dividends is not true?

choices.text: A property dividend is also called a dividend in kind
A property dividend is usually in the form of securities of other entities
The accounting for a property dividend should be based on the carrying amount of the nonmonetary asset transferred
All of these statements are true -----

explanation: Property dividends should be accounted for based on the fair value of the nonmonetary asset transferred, not its carrying amount.

text: Under IFRIC 17, an entity shall measure a noncurrent asset classified as held for distribution to owners at

choices.text: Carrying amount
Lower between choices a and b
Fair value less cost to distribute
Higher between choices a and b -----

explanation: Under IFRIC 17, a noncurrent asset held for distribution to owners should be measured at the lower of its carrying amount and fair value less costs to distribute.

text: Under IFRIC 17, an entity shall measure a liability for noncash asset as dividend to the owners

choices.text: Fair value of the asset to be distributed
Carrying amount of the asset to be distributed
Neither fair value nor carrying amount of the asset to be distributed
Fair value or carrying amount of the asset to be distributed, at the option of the entity -----

explanation: Under IFRIC 17, a liability for a noncash asset dividend should be measured at the fair value of the asset to be distributed.

text: Where the recapitalization involves a reduction in the legal capital of the corporation for the purpose of eliminating an existing deficit, or of writing down the inflated book values, the recapitalization is referred to as

choices.text: Reorganization
Incorporation
Quasi-reorganization
Answer not given -----
