text: Based on Philippine SEC rules, which of the following entities would not normally qualify as SMEs?

choices.text: Entities with total assets between P3 million and P350 million
Entities with total liabilities between P3 million and P250 million
Public utility companies or holders of secondary licenses issued by a regulatory agency
Entities that are not in the process of filing FS for purposes of issuing any class of instrument in a public market

explanation: Public utility companies and holders of secondary licenses issued by regulatory agencies are specifically excluded from qualifying as SMEs under Philippine SEC rules, regardless of their size, due to their public accountability.

text: All of the following can be classified as SMEs, except

choices.text: Commercial bank with total assets of P3 million
Manufacturing entity with total liabilities of P3 million
Merchandising company with total assets of P350 million
Food and beverage chain with total liabilities of P250 million

explanation: Commercial banks cannot be classified as SMEs regardless of their size because they hold assets in a fiduciary capacity for a broad group of outsiders as one of their primary businesses, which gives them public accountability.

text: When did PFRS for SMEs take into effect in the Philippines?

choices.text: January 1, 2008
January 1, 2009
January 1, 2010
January 1, 2011

explanation: PFRS for SMEs became effective in the Philippines on January 1, 2010, as adopted by the Financial Reporting Standards Council (FRSC).

text: Which of the following terms is not descriptive of SMEs?

choices.text: Private entities
Listed companies
Small and medium-sized entities
Non-publicly accountable entities

explanation: Listed companies cannot be SMEs because they have public accountability due to their securities being traded in a public market.

text: Which set of standards shall be used by small publicly-listed entities?

choices.text: Full PFRS
PFRS for SMEs
Either Full PFRS or PFRS for SMEs
Fully PFRS, PFRS for SMEs, or any acceptable accounting basis

explanation: Publicly-listed entities, regardless of their size, must use full PFRS because they have public accountability due to their securities being traded in a public market.

text: In which of the following situations can an entity that does not have public accountability claim compliance with the PFRS for SMEs in its financial statements?

choices.text: The entity prepares its financial statements in accordance with local tax requirements that are substantially the same as the PFRS for SMEs
The entity prepares its financial statements in accordance with local tax requirements that are, except in name, word-for-word the same as full PFRS
The entity prepares its financial statements in accordance with local tax requirements that are, except in name, word-for-word the same as the PFRS for SMEs
In both cases b and c above

explanation: An entity can claim compliance with PFRS for SMEs only if its financial statements are prepared in accordance with requirements that are, except in name, word-for-word the same as PFRS for SMEs.

text: An SME whose only changes to its equity in the periods for which financial statements are presented arise from profit or loss, payment of dividends, corrections of prior period error and changes in accounting policy

choices.text: Is required to present a statement of comprehensive income
Should present a statement of income but not retained earnings
Is required to present a statement of income and retained earnings in place of a statement of comprehensive income
Has the option to present a statement of income and retained earnings in place of a statement of comprehensive income

explanation: Under PFRS for SMEs, an entity has the option to present a statement of income and retained earnings instead of a statement of comprehensive income if its only changes to equity arise from profit or loss, payment of dividends, corrections of prior period errors, and changes in accounting policy.

text: The following statements are based on PFRS for SMEs Statement I: SMEs are entities that do not have public accountability Statement II: SMEs are entities that publish general purpose financial statements for external users Statement III: SMEs are entities that publish special purpose financial statements for internal users

choices.text: True, True, False
True, False, True
False, True, True
False, True, False

explanation: Statement I is true because SMEs are defined as entities that do not have public accountability. Statement II is true because SMEs publish general purpose financial statements for external users. Statement III is false because SMEs do not publish special purpose financial statements for internal users.

text: The following statements are based on PFRS for SMEs Statement I: An entity has public accountability if its debt or equity instruments are traded in a public market Statement II: An entity has public accountability if it is in the process of issuing debt or equity instruments for trading in a public market Statement III: An entity has public accountability if it holds assets in a fiduciary capacity for a broad group of outsiders as one of its primary businesses

choices.text: True, True, True
True, True, False
True, False, True
True, False, False

explanation: All three statements are true. An entity has public accountability if: (1) its securities are traded in a public market, (2) it is in the process of issuing securities for trading in a public market, or (3) it holds assets in a fiduciary capacity for a broad group of outsiders as one of its primary businesses.

text: The following statements are based on PFRS for SMEs Statement I: If an entity's normal operating cycle is not clearly determinable, its duration is assumed to be twelve (12) months Statement II: If an entity is unable to make a reliable estimate of the useful life of an intangible asset, the life shall be presumed to be twenty (20) years Statement III: An entity shall recognize all borrowing costs as an expense in profit or loss in the period in which they are incurred

choices.text: True, True, True
True, False, False
True, False, True
False, False, False

explanation: All three statements are true under PFRS for SMEs: (1) a 12-month operating cycle is assumed if not clearly determinable, (2) a 20-year useful life is presumed for intangible assets if not reliably estimable, and (3) all borrowing costs are expensed as incurred.

text: The following statements refer to PFRS for SMEs Statement I: The PFRS for SMEs is organized by topic, with each topic presented in a separate numbered section Statement II: All of the paragraphs in the PFRS for SMEs, which has a total of 35 sections, have equal authority Statement III: Some sections include appendices of implementation guidance that are not part of the PFRS but, rather, are guidelines for applying it

choices.text: True, True, True
True, False, False
True, False, True
False, False, False

explanation: All three statements are true: (1) PFRS for SMEs is organized into 35 numbered sections by topic, (2) all paragraphs have equal authority, and (3) some sections include non-mandatory implementation guidance in appendices.

text: Which of the following statements is true in relation to an SME?

choices.text: All intangible assets have finite useful life and must be amortized
Investment property is measured at fair value if the fair value can be measured reliably without undue cost or effort on an ongoing basis
Investment in associate shall be accounted for using any of the cost model, fair value model and equity model and using the same accounting policy for all investments in associate
All of these statements are true

explanation: All three statements are true under PFRS for SMEs: (1) all intangible assets are presumed to have finite useful lives and must be amortized, (2) investment property can be measured at fair value if reliably measurable without undue cost, and (3) investments in associates can use any of the three models consistently.

text: An SME can recognize which of the following either as component of profit or loss or component of other comprehensive income?

choices.text: Revaluation surplus
Actuarial gain or loss
Translation gain or loss
Change in fair value of hedging instrument

explanation: Under PFRS for SMEs, translation gains and losses can be recognized either in profit or loss or in other comprehensive income, while the other items must be recognized in other comprehensive income.

text: For small and medium entities, SIRE may under certain conditions replace which two (2) financial statements?

choices.text: Balance Sheet and Income Statement
Income Statement and Statement of Changes in Equity
Balance Sheet and Statement of Comprehensive Income
Statement of Comprehensive Income and Statement of Changes in Equity

explanation: Under PFRS for SMEs, a Statement of Income and Retained Earnings (SIRE) can replace both the Statement of Comprehensive Income and Statement of Changes in Equity if the entity's only changes to equity arise from profit or loss, payment of dividends, corrections of prior period errors, and changes in accounting policy.

text: In accordance with the PFRS for SMEs, the financial statement that presents an entity's assets, liabilities and equity at a point in time

choices.text: Must be titled the balance sheet
Must be titled the statement of financial position
Could be titled the statement of financial position or the balance sheet
Could be titled the statement of financial position, the balance sheet, or any other title that is not misleading

explanation: Under PFRS for SMEs, the financial statement presenting assets, liabilities, and equity can use any title that is not misleading, including "statement of financial position," "balance sheet," or other appropriate titles.

text: Which of the following is not used in accounting for investment in associates and interests in jointly controlled entities of SMEs?

choices.text: Cost model
Equity method
Fair value model
Revaluation model

explanation: Under PFRS for SMEs, investments in associates and jointly controlled entities can be accounted for using the cost model, fair value model, or equity method, but not the revaluation model.

text: Investments in associates must be tested for impairment if the entity uses

choices.text: The cost model or the equity method
The cost model or the fair value model
The equity method or the fair value model
The cost model, equity method or fair value model

explanation: Under PFRS for SMEs, investments in associates must be tested for impairment if the entity uses either the cost model or the equity method. The fair value model does not require impairment testing as changes in fair value are recognized in profit or loss.

text: Which of the following is specifically required to be reported as line item for an SME but not under full PFRS?

choices.text: Financial assets
Investment in joint venture
Non-current assets held for sale
Property, plant and equipment

explanation: Under PFRS for SMEs, investments in joint ventures must be presented as a separate line item in the statement of financial position, while under full PFRS, they can be included within other line items.

text: All of the following are considered line item in the statement of financial position of an SME except

choices.text: Provisions
Revaluation surplus
Non-controlling interest
Equity attributable to the owners of parent

explanation: Under PFRS for SMEs, "equity attributable to the owners of parent" is not a required line item, while provisions, revaluation surplus, and non-controlling interest are required line items.

text: Which is not considered as Other Comprehensive Income (OCI) for SMEs?

choices.text: Some actuarial gains and losses
Some foreign exchange translation gains and losses
Some changes in fair values of hedging instruments
Some gains and losses on FVOCI securities

explanation: Under PFRS for SMEs, gains and losses on financial assets at fair value through other comprehensive income (FVOCI) are not recognized in other comprehensive income, while the other items can be recognized in OCI.

text: Which method is used by SMEs in recognizing revenue from rendering services?

choices.text: Accrual method
Cost recovery method
Installment method
Percentage-of-completion method

explanation: Under PFRS for SMEs, revenue from rendering services is recognized using the accrual method, which recognizes revenue when the service is performed, regardless of when cash is received.

text: Which of the following cannot be accounted for by SMEs under the cost model?

choices.text: Intangible assets
Investment property
Investment in associates
Property, plant and equipment

explanation: Under PFRS for SMEs, investment property cannot be accounted for under the cost model. It must be measured at fair value if the fair value can be measured reliably without undue cost or effort on an ongoing basis.

text: Which of the following is not considered a basic financial instrument for SMEs?

choices.text: Bonds and loans payable
Cash and bank accounts
Commercial paper and bills
Options and warrants

explanation: Under PFRS for SMEs, options and warrants are not considered basic financial instruments. They are classified as other financial instruments due to their derivative nature.

text: Which of the following is not considered as other financial instrument for SMEs?

choices.text: Derivatives
Hedging instruments
Investments in convertible and puttable shares
Investments in non-convertible and non-puttable shares

explanation: Under PFRS for SMEs, investments in non-convertible and non-puttable shares are considered basic financial instruments, while derivatives, hedging instruments, and investments in convertible and puttable shares are considered other financial instruments.

text: What is the basic purpose of the Revised Conceptual Framework? I. To assist FRSC in developing new accounting standards those represent GAAP in the Philippines II. To assist FRSC in reviewing and adopting existing international accounting standards III. To assist preparers of financial statements in applying accounting standards and in dealing with topics those have yet to form the subject of accounting standards

choices.text: I and II only
I and III only
II and III only
I, II and III

explanation: The Revised Conceptual Framework serves all three purposes: (1) assisting the FRSC in developing new standards, (2) helping review and adopt international standards, and (3) guiding preparers in applying standards and dealing with topics not yet covered by specific standards.

text: Which is not within the scope of the Revised Conceptual Framework?

choices.text: Objective of financial statements
Qualitative characteristics of financial statements
Recognition and measurement of basic elements
Generally accepted accounting principles

explanation: The Revised Conceptual Framework does not include generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP). It focuses on the conceptual basis for financial reporting, including objectives, qualitative characteristics, and recognition/measurement concepts.

text: The Revised Conceptual Framework is comprised of how many chapters?

choices.text: Six
Eight
Ten
Twelve

explanation: The Revised Conceptual Framework consists of eight chapters: (1) The Objective of General Purpose Financial Reporting, (2) Qualitative Characteristics of Useful Financial Information, (3) Financial Statements and the Reporting Entity, (4) The Elements of Financial Statements, (5) Recognition and Derecognition, (6) Measurement, (7) Presentation and Disclosure, and (8) Concepts of Capital and Capital Maintenance.

text: Which statement is incorrect concerning the Revised Conceptual Framework?

choices.text: The Framework is not a PFRS and therefore does not define standard for any particular measurement or disclosure issue
The Framework is concerned with general purpose financial statements including consolidated financial statements
In cases of conflict, the requirements of the Framework prevail over those of the relevant PFRS
The Framework applies to the financial statements of all commercial, industrial and business reporting entities, whether in public or private sector

explanation: This statement is incorrect because in cases of conflict, the requirements of the relevant PFRS prevail over the Framework. The Framework is not a standard and does not override specific PFRS requirements.

text: Under the Revised Conceptual Framework of Financial Reporting, users of financial information may be classified into

choices.text: Heavy users management and slight users public, government
Primary users existing and potential investors and creditors and other users
Internal users employees, customers and external users investors, creditors
Main users existing investors, creditors and incidental users potential investors, creditors

explanation: The Revised Conceptual Framework classifies users into primary users (existing and potential investors and creditors) and other users. This classification reflects the Framework's focus on providing information that is useful for making investment and credit decisions.

text: These are related to the economic resources assets, economic obligations liabilities, residual interest equity and changes in them revenue and expense

choices.text: Basic elements
Basic principles
Basic objectives
Basic concepts

explanation: These are the basic elements of financial statements as defined in the Revised Conceptual Framework: assets (economic resources), liabilities (economic obligations), equity (residual interest), and changes in them (revenue and expenses).

text: Which is not within the definition of an asset under the Revised Conceptual Framework?

choices.text: An asset is a present economic resource
The economic resource is a right that has the potential to produce economic benefits
The economic resource is controlled by the entity as a result of past event
Future economic benefit is expected to flow to the entity

explanation: The Revised Conceptual Framework defines an asset as a present economic resource controlled by the entity as a result of past events, where the economic resource is a right that has the potential to produce economic benefits. The expectation of future economic benefits is not part of the definition.

text: What is the new definition of liability under the Revised Conceptual Framework?

choices.text: A present obligation of the entity arising from past event the settlement of which is expected to result in an inflow of economic benefit
A present obligation of the entity arising from present event
A present obligation of the entity to transfer an economic resource as a result of past event
An obligation that the entity has practical ability to avoid

explanation: The Revised Conceptual Framework defines a liability as a present obligation of the entity to transfer an economic resource as a result of past events. This new definition focuses on the obligation to transfer an economic resource rather than the expected outflow of economic benefits.

text: Under the Revised Conceptual Framework, which of the following criteria need not be satisfied for a liability to exist?

choices.text: The entity has an obligation
The obligation is to transfer an economic resource
The obligation is a present obligation that exists as a result of a past event
The settlement of the obligation is expected to result in an outflow of economic benefit

explanation: Under the Revised Conceptual Framework, a liability exists when there is a present obligation to transfer an economic resource as a result of past events. The expectation of an outflow of economic benefits is not a required criterion for a liability to exist.

text: It is the residual interest in the assets of the enterprise after deducting all its liabilities

choices.text: Revenue
Expenses
Net income
Equity

explanation: Equity is defined as the residual interest in the assets of the entity after deducting all its liabilities. It represents the owners' claim on the entity's assets after all obligations have been satisfied.

text: It represents the gross inflows of economic benefits during the period arising in the course of ordinary activities of an enterprise when these inflows result in increases in equity, other than those relating to contributions from owners

choices.text: Assets
Liabilities
Expense
Revenue

explanation: Revenue represents the gross inflows of economic benefits during the period arising in the course of ordinary activities of an enterprise when these inflows result in increases in equity, other than those relating to contributions from owners.

text: It represents the gross outflows of economic benefits during the period arising in the course of ordinary activities of an enterprise when these outflows result in decreases in equity, other than those relating to distributions to owners

choices.text: Assets
Liabilities
Expense
Revenue

explanation: Expenses represent the gross outflows of economic benefits during the period arising in the course of ordinary activities of an enterprise when these outflows result in decreases in equity, other than those relating to distributions to owners.

text: It is defined as increase in economic benefits during the accounting period in the form of inflows or enhancements of assets or decreases in liabilities that result in increases in equity, other than those relating to contributions from equity participants

choices.text: Gain
Income
Profit
Revenue

explanation: Income is defined as increases in economic benefits during the accounting period in the form of inflows or enhancements of assets or decreases in liabilities that result in increases in equity, other than those relating to contributions from equity participants.

text: It is the process of incorporating in the balance sheet or income statement an item that meets the definition of an element of financial statements.

choices.text: Recognition
Allocation
Realization
Summarization

explanation: Recognition is the process of incorporating in the balance sheet or income statement an item that meets the definition of an element of financial statements. It involves both the initial recording of an item and its subsequent inclusion in the financial statements.

text: It is the process of determining the monetary amounts at which the elements are to be recognized and carried in the balance sheet and income statement

choices.text: Measurement
Recognition
Reporting
Interpreting

explanation: Measurement is the process of determining the monetary amounts at which the elements are to be recognized and carried in the balance sheet and income statement. It involves selecting the appropriate measurement basis and applying it to the elements of financial statements.

text: The underlying theme of the Revised Conceptual Framework is

choices.text: Comparability
Decision usefulness
Timeliness
Understandability

explanation: The underlying theme of the Revised Conceptual Framework is decision usefulness. The Framework aims to provide financial information that is useful to users in making economic decisions.

text: In financial accounting, revenues and expenses are often included in the determination of net income even though no cash receipts or disbursements have occurred. This practice is based on the concept of

choices.text: This practice is based on the concept of
Time period
Historical cost
Going concern

explanation: The accrual basis of accounting recognizes revenues and expenses when they are earned or incurred, regardless of when cash is received or paid. This is a fundamental concept in financial accounting that ensures financial statements reflect the economic substance of transactions.

text: This is an assumption by accountants that a business will continue to operate indefinitely unless specific evidences to the contrary exist, as for example, an impending bankruptcy

choices.text: Matching principle
Going concern principle
Cost principle
Objectivity principle

explanation: The going concern principle is the assumption that a business will continue to operate indefinitely unless there is evidence to the contrary. This assumption underlies the preparation of financial statements and affects the valuation of assets and liabilities.

text: Which underlying concept serves as the basis for preparing financial statements at regular intervals?

choices.text: Accounting entity
Going concern
Accounting period
Stable monetary unit

explanation: The accounting period concept provides the basis for preparing financial statements at regular intervals. It allows the continuous life of an entity to be divided into specific time periods for reporting purposes.

text: The financial statements should be stated in terms of a common financial denominator

choices.text: Accrual
Going concern
Time period
Monetary unit

explanation: The monetary unit concept requires that financial statements be stated in terms of a common financial denominator (currency). This allows for the measurement and comparison of different economic resources and obligations.

text: Preparation of consolidated FS when a parent-subsidiary relationship exists is an example of the

choices.text: Comparability characteristic
Economic entity assumption
Neutrality characteristic
Relevance characteristics

explanation: The preparation of consolidated financial statements is based on the economic entity assumption, which views the parent and its subsidiaries as a single economic unit, regardless of their legal status as separate entities.

text: What are the qualitative characteristics of financial statements according to the Revised Conceptual Framework?

choices.text: Qualitative characteristics are broad classes of financial effects of transactions and other events
Qualitative characteristics are the attributes that make the information provided in financial statements useful to others
Qualitative characteristics measure the extent to which an entity has complied with all relevant Standards and Interpretations
Qualitative characteristics are non-quantitative aspects of an entity's position and performance and changes in financial position

explanation: Qualitative characteristics are the attributes that make the information provided in financial statements useful to users. They include fundamental characteristics (relevance and faithful representation) and enhancing characteristics (comparability, verifiability, timeliness, and understandability).

text: Enhancing qualitative characteristics of financial reporting that make information more useful are

choices.text: Verifiability, timeliness, understandability, and time-period
Relevance, reliability, and faithful representation
Comparability, verifiability, timeliness, and understandability
Completeness, neutrality, and freedom from error

explanation: The enhancing qualitative characteristics of financial reporting are comparability, verifiability, timeliness, and understandability. These characteristics complement the fundamental characteristics of relevance and faithful representation.

text: To achieve faithful representation, the financial statements

choices.text: Must have predictive and confirmatory value
Are comparable, understandable, verifiable and timely
Must be complete, neutral and reasonably free from error
All of these would achieve faithful representation

explanation: To achieve faithful representation, financial statements must be complete (including all necessary information), neutral (free from bias), and reasonably free from error. These are the three components of faithful representation.

text: Which qualitative characteristics relate to the content of the financial statements?

choices.text: Relevance and reliability
Understandability
Relevance and understandability
Reliability and comparability

explanation: Relevance and reliability (faithful representation) are the qualitative characteristics that relate to the content of financial statements. They ensure that the information is useful for decision-making and faithfully represents what it purports to represent.

text: Which qualitative characteristics relate to the presentation of financial statements?

choices.text: Relevance and reliability
Understandability and comparability
Relevance and understandability
Reliability and comparability

explanation: Understandability and comparability are the qualitative characteristics that relate to the presentation of financial statements. They ensure that the information is presented in a way that is clear and can be compared with similar information.

text: It is the quality of information that assures readers that the information is free from bias or error and faithfully represents what it purports to show

choices.text: Understandability
Relevance
Reliability
Comparability

explanation: Reliability (faithful representation) is the quality of information that assures readers that the information is free from bias or error and faithfully represents what it purports to show. It includes completeness, neutrality, and freedom from error.

text: Verifiability of financial accounting information is synonymous with

choices.text: Faithful representation
Substance over form
Prudence
Completeness

explanation: Verifiability is an aspect of faithful representation. It means that different knowledgeable and independent observers could reach consensus that a particular depiction is a faithful representation of the economic phenomena it purports to represent.

text: Which term best describes information that influences the economic decisions of users?

choices.text: Prospective
Relevant
Reliable
Understandable

explanation: Relevant information is capable of making a difference in the decisions made by users. It has predictive value, confirmatory value, or both, and is material.

text: If financial information that is presented in a balance sheet or income statement is misstated, and it influences the economic decisions of user, that information is described as

choices.text: Faithful
Material
Prudent
Reliable

explanation: Information is material if omitting it or misstating it could influence decisions that users make on the basis of the financial information. Materiality is an aspect of relevance.

text: Freedom from error relates to which qualitative characteristic of the Revised Conceptual Framework?

choices.text: Faithful representation
Relevance
Understandability
Verifiability

explanation: Freedom from error is one of the components of faithful representation. It means that the information is accurate and complete, with no errors or omissions in the description of the economic phenomena.

text: Which of the following terms describing information in the financial statements are properly matched?

choices.text: Prudent and relevant
Reliable and verifiable
Unbiased and neutral
Understandable and comparable

explanation: Neutrality (being unbiased) is a component of faithful representation. It means that the information is free from bias in its selection or presentation, and does not favor one party over another.

text: Under IFRS Revised Conceptual Framework, it is the ability through consensus among independent observers to ensure that financial information represents what it purports to represent

choices.text: Comparability
Feedback value
Relevance
Verifiability

explanation: Verifiability is the ability through consensus among independent observers to ensure that financial information represents what it purports to represent. It helps assure users that the information faithfully represents the economic phenomena it purports to represent.

text: What links the decision makers and the decisions they make so that financial information would be useful?

choices.text: Materiality
Relevance
Reliability
Understandability

explanation: Relevance is what links the decision makers and the decisions they make. Information is relevant if it is capable of making a difference in the decisions made by users.

text: In respect to information included in financial statements, the accounting concept of prudence ensures that

choices.text: The financial statements report what they purport to report
A degree of caution in the exercise of judgments about estimates is made
Information is provided to users within the same time period in which it is most likely to bear on their decisions
An appropriate balance is achieved between the relevance and the reliability of information that has been included

explanation: Prudence is the exercise of caution when making judgments under conditions of uncertainty. It ensures that assets and income are not overstated and liabilities and expenses are not understated.

text: Which of the following interacts with both relevance and reliability to contribute to the usefulness of information?

choices.text: Comparability
Timeliness
Neutrality
Predictive value

explanation: Comparability interacts with both relevance and reliability to contribute to the usefulness of information. It enables users to identify and understand similarities and differences between items.

text: Which of the following is an ingredient of the primary quality of relevance?

choices.text: Predictive value
Materiality
Understandability
Verifiability

explanation: Predictive value is an ingredient of relevance. Information has predictive value if it can be used as an input to processes employed by users to predict future outcomes.

text: This refers to the tendency of accountants to resolve uncertainty in a way least likely to overstate assets and revenues?

choices.text: Comparability
Materiality
Conservatism
Consistency

explanation: Conservatism (prudence) is the tendency to resolve uncertainty in a way that is least likely to overstate assets and revenues. It is a constraint on the exercise of judgment in financial reporting.

text: Which of the following is an example of the concept of conservatism?

choices.text: Stating inventories at the lower of cost or net realizable value
Stating inventories using the FIFO method in periods of rising prices
Using the percentage-of-completion method in the first year of a long-term construction contract
Using the interest method instead of the straight-line method to record interest in the first year of a long-term receivable

explanation: Stating inventories at the lower of cost or net realizable value is an example of conservatism because it ensures that assets are not overstated and potential losses are recognized.

text: The cost of an inexpensive fountain pen which has an estimated life of five years was treated as an expense of the period when purchased. It is an example of the application of the

choices.text: It is an example of the application of the
Consistency principle
Matching principle
Materiality principle

explanation: The materiality principle allows for the immediate expensing of immaterial items, even if they have a long useful life. The cost of an inexpensive fountain pen is immaterial and can be expensed immediately.

text: In the event of conflict between the economic substance of a transaction and its legal form, the economic substance shall prevail. This concept is known as

choices.text: Form over substance
Substance over form
Faithful representation
Completeness

explanation: The substance over form concept requires that transactions be accounted for according to their economic substance rather than their legal form. This ensures that financial statements faithfully represent the economic reality of transactions.

text: The financial accounting information is directed toward the common needs of users and is independent of presumptions about particular needs and desires of specific users

choices.text: Relevance
Verifiability
Neutrality
Completeness

explanation: Neutrality means that financial information is directed toward the common needs of users and is independent of presumptions about particular needs and desires of specific users. It ensures that information is free from bias.

text: It is the exercise of care and caution in dealing with uncertainties in measurement so as not to overstate assets and income and not understated liabilities and expenses

choices.text: Completeness
Prudence
Faithful representation
Neutrality

explanation: Prudence is the exercise of care and caution in dealing with uncertainties in measurement. It ensures that assets and income are not overstated and liabilities and expenses are not understated.

text: It is the result of the standard of adequate disclosure

choices.text: Faithful representation
Substance over form
Neutrality
Completeness

explanation: Completeness is the result of adequate disclosure. It means that all information necessary for users to understand the economic phenomena being depicted is included in the financial statements.

text: The Revised Conceptual framework of accounting sets out two constraints when implementing accounting procedures. What are they?

choices.text: Cost-benefit and cost principle
Timeliness and revenue principle
Cost principle and revenue principle
Cost-benefit and timeliness

explanation: The Revised Conceptual Framework identifies two constraints on financial reporting: (1) cost-benefit (the benefits of providing information should exceed the costs) and (2) timeliness (information should be available to users in time to be capable of influencing their decisions).

text: Which of the following accounting concepts states that an accounting transaction should be supported by sufficient evidence to allow two or more qualified individuals to arrive at essentially similar conclusions?

choices.text: Conservatism
Objectivity
Periodicity
Stable monetary unit

explanation: The objectivity concept requires that accounting transactions be supported by sufficient evidence to allow two or more qualified individuals to arrive at essentially similar conclusions. This is related to verifiability.

text: Timeliness is an ingredient of

choices.text: Reliability
Relevance
Verifiability
Adequate financial statements

explanation: Timeliness is an ingredient of relevance. Information is relevant only if it is available to users in time to be capable of influencing their decisions.

text: Which of the following is an example of the expense recognition principle of associating cause and effect?

choices.text: Allocation of insurance cost
Sales commissions
Depreciation of property, plant and equipment
Officers salaries

explanation: Sales commissions are an example of associating cause and effect because they are directly related to the revenue they help generate. The expense is recognized in the same period as the related revenue.

text: The application of costs against revenue in measuring the periodic income is called

choices.text: Income statement preparation
Profit and loss preparation
Bookkeeping process
Matching process

explanation: The matching process is the application of costs against revenue in measuring periodic income. It ensures that expenses are recognized in the same period as the related revenues.

text: Which of the following is an application of the principle of systematic and rational allocation?

choices.text: Amortization of intangible assets
Sales commissions
Research and development costs
Officers salaries

explanation: Amortization of intangible assets is an example of systematic and rational allocation because it allocates the cost of the asset over its useful life in a systematic and rational manner.

text: Which of the following principles best describes the conceptual rational for the method of matching depreciation with revenue?

choices.text: Associating cause and effect
Systematic and rational allocation
Immediate recognition
Partial recognition

explanation: Depreciation is an example of systematic and rational allocation because it allocates the cost of a long-lived asset over its useful life in a systematic and rational manner.

text: A patent with a ten-year life was determined to be worthless. The write off of the asset is an example of which of the following principles?

choices.text: Associating cause and effect
Immediate recognition
Profit maximization
Classification

explanation: The write-off of a worthless patent is an example of immediate recognition because the entire cost is recognized as an expense in the period when the patent is determined to be worthless.

text: Which among the following equations best exemplifies the entity theory of accounting?

choices.text: Assets = Liabilities + Capital
Assets – Liabilities = Capital
Assets + Liabilities = Capital
Assets – Liabilities – Preferred SHE = Common SHE

explanation: The basic accounting equation, Assets = Liabilities + Equity, best exemplifies the entity concept. It shows that the entity's assets are equal to the claims against those assets (liabilities and equity).

text: Generally, revenue should be recognized at a point when

choices.text: Management decides it is appropriate to do so
The product is available for sale to the ultimate consumer
An exchange has taken place and the earnings process is virtually complete
A customers order for a definite amount of merchandise has been received for shipment at FOB destination later

explanation: Revenue should be recognized when there is an exchange transaction and the earnings process is substantially complete. This means the entity has performed its obligations and can reasonably expect to receive the economic benefits.

text: The term matching costs and revenues means that

choices.text: All costs should be allocated to certain accounting periods on the basis of the effect on revenues
Costs which can be associated directly with specific revenue should be carried forward on the balance sheet until the associated revenue is recognized
Costs should be carried forward to future accounting periods if they have not resulted in revenue during the current accounting period
If costs are charged off as expense in the accounting period when they are actually incurred, they will be matched properly with revenues earned during that accounting period

explanation: The matching principle requires that costs be recognized in the same period as the related revenues. When costs can be directly associated with specific revenue, they should be carried forward as assets until the related revenue is recognized.

text: Which of the following conditions does not apply to the recognition of revenue for transactions involving rendering of services?

choices.text: The amount of revenue can be measured reliably
It is probable that payment for services shall be received
The significant risks and rewards of ownership have been transferred to the buyer
The costs incurred and the costs to complete can be measured reliably

explanation: The transfer of significant risks and rewards of ownership is a condition for recognizing revenue from the sale of goods, not from the rendering of services. For services, the key conditions are reliable measurement of revenue and costs, and probability of payment.

text: Revenue is recognized when

choices.text: It is probable that future economic benefits will flow to the enterprise
The future economic benefits can be measured reliably
It is possible that reliably measurable future economic benefits will flow to the enterprise
It is probable that reliably measurable future economic benefits will flow to the enterprise

explanation: Revenue should be recognized when it is probable (more likely than not) that reliably measurable future economic benefits will flow to the enterprise. Both probability and reliable measurement are required conditions.

text: Normally, revenue is recognized

choices.text: When the customers order is received
When the customers order is accompanied by a check
Only if the transaction will create an account receivable
When the title to the goods changes

explanation: For sales of goods, revenue is normally recognized when the title to the goods changes, which typically occurs at the point of delivery. This is when the significant risks and rewards of ownership are transferred to the buyer.

text: Under what methods is revenue recognized prior to delivery?

choices.text: Percentage of completion method
Cost recovery method
Installment sales
Accrual method

explanation: The percentage of completion method recognizes revenue as work progresses on long-term contracts, prior to delivery. This method is used when the outcome of the contract can be estimated reliably and the contract is expected to be profitable.
